description:
The restaurant was clean inside. We were the only table inside however for dinner. Food was promptly served and we were checked on by the server. They have cold soju. 
We had the jjampong the seafood noodle soup. 4 stars: the noodles were just right and the soup had a lot of flavor. I however I wish it would have been more spicy. 
We also had the grilled mackerel. 5 stars: the fish was firm and not dry. Very flavorful and oily as a mackerel should be. 
Spicy chicken 3 stars: we were disappointed with this as it's hard to do spicy chicken wrong. It was just all sauce.
author: Jelly J.

description:
This place has a very good food. I loved it.
But but the service sucks.
I went there with my friends and when we were about to pay the bill the waitress was angry because we give her a 15% tip . And then she demanded us  to give to her 20% tip. She called us cheap.
author: Iane Soalheiro Aquino S.

description:
We were craving Korean and didn't realize there are a few options in union square.  This one had mixed review but overall it served its purpose for us.  We were able to book 15 min before on a sat night and got nice seating.  There were seven side dishes although two of them tasted a bit off.  The kimchi pickled radish was sour.  The bean sprouts, fish cake and broccoli were yummy. 

As for main dish, we had 
- bibimbap in stone pot with beef.  5 Stars super yummy. I rarely like this as here is usually too much rice and not enough veggie.  This one was delicious
- bulgogi.  2 Stars as it was obviously overcooked and chewy - a reason we may never come back or at least not order that again
- soft tofu stew.  Was what I expected and goo enough 3.5 Stars

As for service, I am not sure she is racist as others would suggest but definitely lacking a certain warm feeling.  She seems to be the only person serving the whole restaurant and so felt slow at times and then when we asked for more side dishes, hard to tell if she is judging us or just feeling over worked. 

We may go back as the bibimbap was memorable. Will see 
-
author: Lei H.

description:
Taste - ****
Service - **
Price - $$$
Interior - **

Interior - Interior is so dark. I guess the light is ok but overall wall and tables and chairs are dark. There are many tables and really good for larger group. 

Food - Most of foods are great. But cold noddle is worst. I often ate korean style chinese food. Black noddle, spicy noddle, sweet and sour fried pork all good. Side dishes are also tasty. 


Service - Service was not bad. However, when I left after pay, server asked me to give more tip. At that time, I ordered cold noddle and it was really terrible. I could not eat at all. So I gave tip.less than 15% The tip is to pay as much as I am satisfied with the service I receive, but they have no right to ask.
author: Da Won L.

description: I give this place a 3.5. I would say this place is mediocre. The one thing I loved was how spacious and quiet the place was. Its pretty hard to find quiet dining in SF but this place was very peaceful in terms of atmosphere and noise level. That being said, I ordered sullungtang and was pretty disappointed at how lukewarm it was. I wanted hot soup not lukewarm/cold. The menu is really extensive though so I will try this place out a couple more times since they have some korean food not sold by alot of places. I really want to try their jambbong and some of the fish soups/stews next time. The jajangmyun or black bean noodles were good- not excellent but not bad.
author: Emily P.

description:
I haven't written a review for restaurant for quite awhile now. Not much of a street eater no more...lolz, kidding.
My bestie and I were looking for a nice and cozy place to celebrate our Christmas. Unfortunately, unlike last year, this year was so crowded. Lines of people were everywhere. We went to Tenderloin and even there was the same situation. Accidentally, we walked pass DB. I heard good things about this but always hesitated to go on in bcoz many of my Korean friends said the food is only mediocre but quite pricey. There was no option thus, we were starving. We walked in. The ambience was good. There wasn't a crowd. Yay! The seat was comfy. Staff were extremely friendly. 

Food came out fast and the portion was huge (for us girls). We was so hungry so forgot to take many photos. Only captured one. We ordered military soup, add seafood (end up with 4 bowls of rice coz it was so good); ramen; kimchi pancake. Many side dishes. I think the price might be considered pricey as the small size is approx $14 and the large is $24 and over. However, the portion is good. We were stuff and couldn't barely walk...
Taste wise, it isn't as tasty as Aria (my fav pop and mom place) but to compare, I like this better than COcoBang or 707 Sutter and the price isn't much different to Sutter place. If you go by yourself, perhaps it is, but to go with a friend, I'd highly recommend this restaurant. Plus, it is very clean!!!
Would definitely come back for my birthday, I want seaweed soup and Chicken soup with sticky rice!!!
author: Bao V.

description:
Went on a Friday night and we were the only ones in the restaurant. We were a party of 7, 5 being kids, and were charged 20% tip. She just nonchalantly gave us the bill and told us tip was already included. How rude!!! I didn't know tip was required. We are very generous tippers but these moments really make me upset.

As for the food, the black noodles were soggy, the vegetable in the bibimbap tasted like it was about to go bad, and sweet and sour pork didn't have too much flavor, and the fried dumplings were ok.
author: Christina S.

description:
I am appalled at the negative reviews here.  This place is fantastic for so many reasons.

1) The food is great here.  It's not the best Korean you will ever have but it is solid and authentic.  It's also not Korean BBQ, it's Korean cuisine.  I hate to break it to those who don't realize but Korean cuisine is not just barbecuing your own meat and making your clothes and hair smell like smoke and sweat.  There is a lot more to it and this restaurant's very big and comprehensive menu is representative of that.

2) It is frequented by a large Korean customer base, many of those I've spoken to maintain that the food is authentic.

3) The decor and atmosphere is legit. Those wanting high ceilings, parquet wood flooring, faux-antique pendant lights and subway tiles have no place in a real Korean restaurant.  The mismatched chairs, the overly-ornate wood dividing walls, the lucky talismans and charms hanging on the walls, the soju and beer posters/calendars with pictures of ladies in bikinis, the tvs  playing Korean news channels, the unflattering bright lighting....these are all nostalgic things which make up an authentic Korean family restaurant experience.  Especially at a Korean restaurant, having large plastic cups, water jugs, bottles of beer & soju and drinking glasses, various dishes, eating and serving plates, all on large tables which are still too small that you have no idea where everything is going to go makes this atmosphere authentic. I REALLY cannot express enough how much atmosphere makes an Asian restaurant authentic or full of crap.

4) The owners/servers here are the perfect blend of sweet, in your face, friendly and impatient.  The aunties and uncles working in places like this don't have time for western formalities.  It's all about the attitude.  Best chance you have is to be as equally and amicably as forward as they are, or to be ultra humble and extra smiley.  I really cannot stress enough how one should not be overly demanding or expect red carpet service at places like this.  It won't work in your favor.

We ordered the Kimchijeon (kim chi pancake), steamed mandu (dumplings), Nak Ji Jun Gol (octopus in a spicy sauce), Kal Bi (of course), Jap Chae (of course), Sam Gae Tang (ginseng chicken "soup").  They were all great great great.  The Ginseng Chicken was on the bland side but as this type of dish is often eaten for medicinal purposes, that was not surprising.  We did not order the Kimchijigae as we normally do but will try it next time since....WE WILL DEFINITELY BE BACK!

Love love love this place!
author: Adrian C.

description:
First customer on a Thursday morning. Ordered food, food came, server was really nice- until the $45 bill came and I gave her $51. 

Her "Excuse me, this isn't enough"
Me "Oh it says $45"
Her "Yes you need to give me one more dollar. $7 is 15% tip"
Me "Actually I don't have to tip at all it's not mandatory" 

I pack up and go back to talk her. Maybe I overlooked their gratuity policy. She tells me no, tip isn't included and proceeds to tell me that "but in America you tip 15-20%" 

I TELL HER BETC- "I'm not obligated to tip you at all in America. You know that right? You don't go around chasing ppl for tip." 

She goes ok ok you don't need to you don't need to while backing into the kitchen. 

Lets talk about this over coffee, lady w the straight short black hair and bangs.
author: Amy L.

description: nice homey environment  best jjangjangmyeon I've had since I was in korea! Also our waiter, possibly owner?, was a really nice and sweet woman. Friends ordered the ddeokboki and said it was great as well!
author: Abby D.

description:
This is a solid Korean restaurant. The service is attentive and the food is delicious. I've had tofu stew, stone pot bibimbap, and kimchi pancake here, and they were all great.

With your meal, you'll get a good assortment of banchan that are tasty and well-made. I will say that I haven't seen my favorite one (sweet potato in syrup) for a while. 

The decor is dated, but who cares? Not me! I come to Dong Baek to eat, and I always leave satisfied. I will be coming back again and again to work my way through more of their large menu.
author: Matthew L.

description:
This past Saturday, after some intense rainy day retail therapy my friend and I were craving something warm and meaty - DB was the only Korean joint in the Tenderloin that was open on a Saturday afternoon (707 and Coco weren't open yet).

We were seated immediately and knew exactly what we wanted the moment we sat down - bibibop dolsot. Within minutes the nice server brought us an array of banchan (the small dishes) and we went to town! Heads up - DB DOES NOT serve anchovies... I know because I specifically asked for some. 

Our bibibop dolset came out quickly. We ate. And left.

DB is a great, fast, and convenient spot in the Tenderloin for folks craving Korean BBQ. However the food and ambiance are "just ok," which makes DB kind of pricey considering how much you're paying.
author: John L.

description:
The owner put the tip by herself 
20% tip for lunch???
And I we didn't serviced by anyone
Also the food it's not rly good
And expensive than other Korean restaurant
It's a awful experience
author: Alan H.

description:
Extensive menu, friendly service, and lots of seating. And they have televisions if you wanna watch a game... or Korean dramas. Mmhmm, you do you. 

I appreciate the soup/ stew options. Good ban chan variety (with refills as requested). Tasty seafood pancake, dumplings, etc. The jajangmyeon (black bean noodles) fell short though- not enough flavor. 

Overall, a solid option for Korean food in this part of town.
author: Joanna L.

description:
Came here of Friday late night for the first time.
Pretty crowded with Korean customers (good sign)
We ordered small seafood pancake, cod roe bean paste soup, pork spareribs. 
Their portion is huge so be careful when you order !
We definitely ordered way too much !!
The two servers were working hard, maybe short handed for Friday night...
We are not from SF but we will come back when we visit SF again
author: Sati I.

description:
The staff here are friendly but as a Korean I must say the food is in dire need of some help. Been here twice, have tried the meat dishes as well as the samgyetang (whole chicken with sticky rice soup). The meat dishes were relatively flavorless and tough, and the soup was so bland, even after adding salt. It tasted like someone just slow cooked a chicken in water in hopes that that would somehow taste good.

Would not recommend this place to anyone. Jin Mi is nearby and the quality is so much better.
author: Davis K.

description:
Very racism restaurant. With mandatory tip. There should have a poster in the front of the door that says Not Welcome to Any Race, Except Korean. When I have a dinner in this restaurant, there is 3 groups of Korean sit around me. The server is so polite and nice when any time she serve the Korean table. I try to say thanks for she served me, but she ignored me and place plates very messy. And did not serve anymore to me when she keep talking to others. That is not the first time happened on me in this restaurant. I think tips is build up by the attitude of services. I spend $22.73 for this and add two dollars for the tip of  below-average-service-attitude. The server mandator me to give one more dollar for "enough". This restaurant has good food but not enough for the price and attitude. If you have any other options, don't choose this restaurant.

这家韩国餐厅歧视华人，小费也高。不值得去。
author: Zhu Z.

description:
Large portions and a generous amount of the free small plate appetizers. The stone pot bi bim bap ingredients tasted fresh but lacked taste in general. Unfortunately I felt the rice in the bi bim bap was too wet and that made mixing (and rice crispness) less than ideal. It's better than some surrounding Korean spots like 707 and coco bang in terms of atmosphere/authenticity and food quality but I wouldn't recommend this over better Korean spots in town. 

They have a large selection but as I came on my own, I could only try my favorite dish.
author: Eddie L.

description:
Come here with a larger group to make it more worth the $$. I got HELLA chicken pieces which was cool but hard to finish in one meal. I don't think I could taste the chicken at all because the sauce was spicy af and a little too sweet. 

That's basically all I got so can't comment on anything else. I guess the small plate appetizers were pretty good--I liked the sweet potato and fish cake things.
author: Lydia Z.

description:
It always makes me sad when reviewing Korean food places in SF. Why is it so hard to get just regular Korean food right in SF? 

My friend and I stopped by at around 9pm (this place is open late yay) and she ordered the soft tofu soup (soondubu) and I ordered the seollungtang which is a thick and rich beef broth soup. They brought out small salad plates, and their side dishes were fine - nothing special.
But the soft tofu soup was overly sweet and tasted like they used instant ramen powder (not saying its a bad taste but shouldnt taste that from a restaurant soft tofu soup). My soup was not at all thick or rich but very clear and watery. 
On top of it all, the prices are way expensive for what they really should be.

Maybe i will come back for some late night korean food cravings if I am in the area but overall disappointed :c
author: Grace P.

description:
This place has a nice homey more traditional feel to it than 707 but I've got to say the prices are a bit steep especially being in the tenderloin.

My tofu soup had lots of meat and tofu but at $13.99, thought it was a little more than I'm used to paying. There wasn't even a raw egg that we could crack into it. We also ordered ja ja mein noodles which was also $13.99.

There was one server but we managed to get at least one refill of our ban chan.
author: Lauren K.

description: Food are either too salty or too sweet. We order seafood pancake and and jajian mien. The seafood is over cook. The food is alright and too pricey.
author: Qing L.

description: Authentic Korean food (lots of natives there), big portions (with generous banchan), nice ambience. Decent price and lunch menu available for weekdays.
author: David Y.

description: The service was friendly and attentive.  A slight language barrier as regards to ordering our meals.  The food was "good ", very traditional.  If you enjoy traditional Korean food, great restaurant.  But if you're more into a Korean / American food experience, this might not be the place for you.
author: Felix S.

description:
Been here a couple times now, and I've always left a happy camper!

I've tried a couple of their dishes, including their kalbi, black bean noodle sauce, bibimbop, spicy rice noodles, corn/cheese plate, and a couple I cant think of right now and all are so good. They're staff is super friendly and accommodating. They also bring you banchan that includes cucumbers, kimchi, bean sprouts, fish cake, daikon, broccoli, and seaweed. 

This place is pretty pricey, but considering that it's located in DTSF, it's kind of expected. Give this place a try if you're in the neighborhood!
author: Carrie L.

description:
Traditional Korean food minus the Korean BBQ. My mom and I came here on a week day for lunch. The place was not too busy and the only people who came in were Korean. I'll take that as a good sign. We actually live a couple blocks away and has walked by this place for over 20 years. Never have we thought to come here. The outside looks very unassuming but the decor of the inside is very clean, organized, and has a nice Korean theme. One waitress who gave a pretty decent service- nothing amazing. We ordered the bi bim bap and the noodles with bean sauce. They gave a good amount of side dishes and also a side salad. Our two entrees were pretty big and we basically finished one dish and took the other home. The flavor was very good. 

I would come back.
author: Sarah C.

description:
This place looks like a rundown on the outside but the food was great. So many banchans and all of them were tasty.
Also not many Korean restaurants serve authentic Korean Food in SF, but this place serves authentic Korean food.
author: Yun Young C.

description: I initially chose this Korean spot because it had a vegetarian menu. My mom ordered a bibimbap dish which she enjoyed and I ordered a vegetarian dish; stir fried veggies in a black bean sauce with noodles. There was a misunderstanding and I got served the same dish with meat. Thankfully it wasn't a problem to get my order fixed. Our waiter was nice as was the woman who sat us at our table. Prices were a bit higher, but you do get a lot of food. You could easily share a dish with someone or if you have a large group.
author: Jessica N.

description: Dong Baek and I have a long, long history. I been going to this place since 2004, when I was a we lad of 22. I have gone on first dates, to parties, lunches, hang over lunches, after movies, before movies and now for my own birthday I went there. Back in the day...the service was rude but the food was very good. Spicy and hardy and just plain delicious. On the dates I have taken there (all were women of Korean decent) they were impressed. This was the go to place for the Korean international students to get a tiny taste of Home. Fast forward to 2017...granted I have not been here in about 8 years. I did not realize it was still there and I decided to go there. I ordered the soondae (Korean blood sausage or Korean black pudding) and a small sea food pancake. The soondae was very delicious but the pancake and the banchan (side dishes) were mediocre. The server an older woman not the angry mid thirty (yet kind of hot) server of the famed angry but delicious Days was long gone. The server was cute and friendly but the food except the soondae was kind of meh. Not spicy or salty or sweet just kind of for an older audience. I give the place 4 stars cause of the nostalgia factor but had this been my first time eating there I would have given maybe 3 or 2 stars...the soondae was amazing and tasted fresh and steamed and not microwaved like that place Arang does...
author: Julian F.

description:
On another very special date, we decided to get some Asian food. Just a block away from the apartment, we found this Korean joint that seemed to offer a  pretty diverse menu. Time to check out another place! 

The look was a bit outdated. Blue carpets and light wood around the joint definitely needed a face lift. The staff was alright. Although no one was in the restaurant, they didn't seem to have a lot of patience. My date asked a bunch of questions and they seemed to be irritated by those questions. That made it very uncomfortable for us. No worries, I helped to ease the situation however, the staff shouldn't do that. 

For dinner, I got the Stone Pot Bi Bim Bob for $13.95. Steamed rice and vegetables topped  with egg and beef, served in a stone pot. I'm always a big fan of this dish, no matter the restaurant. Veggies include peppers, carrots, cucumbers, bean sprouts and brought a very crunchy and fresh flavor to the dish. The white rice was sticky and did a great job binding everything together. Add Korean hot sauce to this and you've got a super awesome meal! 

Overall, the place is worth coming back to. Nothing of a stand out but certainly not bad. The food definitely made up for the service, I can tell you that! If you're in the Tenderloin, drop by this place and check them out for some good Korean food!
author: Rockne H.

description:
Smack dab within the Tenderloin is this spicy Korean spot, and their offerings are so large-portioned that you may wish to reconsider quantity of dishes you're ordering -- they're huge!

On our second visit, we "only" shared two [large] plates, thanks to other menu pics (I would suggest a website for a menu this extensive...!):

-96) Spicy & Sweet Pork Feet: Spicy & sweet boiled pork feet served with seasoned sauce
-24) Spicy Octopus and Noodle: Spicy stir fried octopus and vegetables served with somen noodles
-Corn cheese mix on the house
-Sake

I found the corn extremely helpful in diffusing the spiciness of our octopus dish. It was surprising how quick both dishes were served up to us, especially considering how much food was on each plate. Really enjoyed the pork flavor and its vegetables -- the carrots in particular. Octopus was decent in flavor, and by far the spicier dish, though a tad chewy.

When we visited here the previous year, we ordered the Gul Bo Ssam. Not only was there an endless amount, but spice levels skyrocketed beyond my capabilities. This second visit's menu choices were better handled!

Two other things I remember here:
1) We got our order and food pretty quick. The bill, however...
2) This was the second restaurant within two weeks for someone spill a beverage on my mobile device. It still works well enough for you to be reading this posting, but ay carumba!
author: Garett T.

description:
I was surprised that the restaurant only got 3.5 so here I come, for justice. If 707 for the hyper nighty young adults and Cocobang for the drunk, then Dong Baek is definitely that grandma's food for family or mature you and your friends during the day. What you can expect from here is the warm homey atmosphere and the side dishes that you would expect from watching Korean dramas--I don't watch those, again, I don't.

My suggestions:
Jajangmyeon or Jangban Jajang (noodle in black bean sauce)
Dol Sot Bibimbap (The real deal bibimbap in the stone pot)
Hot Tofu Seafood Soup
Bibimnaengmyun (cold noodles)

The Spicy Squid and Chicken Gizzard is too chewy for my taste.

If you think the price is a bit pricier than other places in downtown, you may want to come in lunch time for the same portion with cheaper price. Other than that, it's understandable since the place is nice, bright and the food is well-served.
author: Tran N.

description:
Visiting from Los Angeles, going off of yelp we decided to come here so we could feed my kid dinner and if it wasn't for my screaming son I would of gotten pissed off at the ajuma and waiter who is maybe the son. 

In reality this place is -5 stars for the sub par Korean food and most of all the cheap ajuma that was straight out just cheap. Since my kid was cranky and tired I asked the ajuma to pack up the food. 

We ordered the following:

Gamjatang:  $39.95 - Average

Omurrice: $14.95 - just rice and some veggies thrown in, no taste and bland

Pajun: $12.95 - First of all I asked for non seafood and she came out later asking if it's ok that there is some seafood so we said fine. Of course when it comes out its full of seafood and fucking soggy. Now I'm getting pissed off, at least remake it, but she was being too fucking cheap to remake it. 

Large Hite: $6.50

Banchan: Average, didn't even offer to refill any of it

Here is the kicker, when I asked her to pack up the food, which we didnt even touch since we were trying to tend to my cranky kid, she asked if we wanted all the food, I was like, yeah, we didn't even eat it. I could sense the hesitation that it was either a waste of their to go boxes or she was just too fucking lazy. She basically shoved in as much of the gamjatang into 2 containers and didn't bother bringing another container for the remaining and asked if i wanted to just finish it. Holding back my annoyance, I said no, my kid is screaming can you pack it up. Did she pack the remaining? No. 

I paid $80 plus a $12 tip, why did I tip still? Cause I'm not a cheap fucking douche like the ajuma. If your reading this, I'm embarassed for you. Pathetic.

Stay away from here, I basically grew up in K-town in Los Angeles and this is a poor excuse of a Korean Restaurant. The ajuma can get away with her antics here in SF cause there isn't much in terms of Korean food, if she was in Los Angeles, Koreans would tear her a new one and put her out of business.
author: Ken Y.

description: I just came here from lunch. The gal bi is amazing- juicy, tender and really good marinade. Really great banchan. People are really nice. Great deal for lunch. They also have Korean Chinese food- and will try to come back. Highly recommend this place.
author: Francis G.

description:
this place is pretty good! spacious and good decor - old school high back chairs and all!  we ordered - korean fried chicken, soondoubu jigae, seafood pancake, and kalbi.  i think my fave was the kalbi, which is atypical, but it was just so flavorful and juicy and delicious..

the pancake was packed with seafood, which was awesome, but very dough-y.  i didnt enjoy the dipping sauce as much with it either, not a lot of flavor. the korean wings werent spicy, which was disappointing, i was looking for a lot of spice on that! the soup was pretty good - lots of veggies nom nom... everything was easily washed down with 2 large things of beer. hehe. $100 before tax for three. 

overall good experience! would come back!
author: Christina L.

description: Never wrote a comment before but this restaurant is the best Korean restaurant I've ever eaten!!! Highly recommend!!!!!!
author: Yifei D.

description:
Food (4/5): My bf got the dolsot beef bibimbap, and I got the mandu soup - pretty solid, nothing super special. There were about 8 banchan dishes, which were all really fresh!

Service (2.5/5): Service was friendly at first, but got decidedly worse as the meal went on - I think they wanted us to leave since it was pretty empty, even though it was a couple hours before closing time.

Value (3.5/5): Definitely cheaper Korean food in the Sunset, but prices were decent for the portion and the amount of banchan we ate.
author: Abby S.

description:
Yes, I do recognize that Dong Baek sounds like the title of a pornographic film about birds into oral copulation, but that titillating prospect is not what lured Jamie W. and me to this Tenderloin hotpot hot spot. No, we were hoping lightning would strike again with a Korean place we haven't tried before. After all, Dame Fortune smiled upon us not once but twice in the Temescal area of Oakland with Sahn Maru and Casserole House. However, she wasn't in as good a mood this time as she merely smirked and belched at Dong Baek. We liked it OK but then again, we ain't that picky when we're starving and shaking in our boots in the 'Loin after dark.

It wasn't crowded when we entered the modest place. A Korean soap opera was playing on two big-screen TVs, something culturally enriching about a young girl who discovers she's pregnant when another boy is getting ready to pop the question. The slut. Anyway, Dong Baek wins our award for most banchan plates - 14 (see photo). That was all fine, but what Jamie was jonesing for was the Dol Sot Bibim Bab sizzling in a stone pot. He also wanted kimchi, so it only made sense for him to order the $12.50 Kim Chee Dol Sot Bi Bim Bab (see photo). Unfortunately, we didn't notice the fine detail in the description which didn't include any beef, and so he was disappointed his protein wasn't present.

What made matters worse was that he also ordered the $10.95 Kim Chee Fried Rice, which with the fried egg on top, was almost identical to the bibimbop he ordered (see photo). It was like a double order of kimchi fried rice. Not that we were complaining because we like kimchi, but I could have gone for more variety. Now what I ordered, Jamie couldn't really stomach. It was the $17.95 platter of Pork Feet, boiled and sliced thinly with a marinade that I liked (see photo). He thought it was too gelatinous, but I rather like the consistency of this little piggy and had no problem devouring most of it by myself. Now this little piggy (moi!) didn't go "wee wee wee" all the way home. We just shrugged our pairs of respective shoulders and concluded there is better Korean food to be found in Oakland.

FOOD - 3 stars...relatively decent Korean, just nothing all that outstanding except those pig's feet, an acquired taste, I know
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...well-kept with a side area for louder patrons, I assume
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...they were running around like they were on fire...maybe that's part of the Tenderloin mindset
TOTAL - 3 stars...good Korean, just not that great
author: Ed U.

description: I'm Korean and consider food in Dong Baek pretty decent. I dine there once or twice a week regularly, usually choosing a nice bowl of dolsot bibimbap (hot stone bibimbap). The staffs are always welcoming and courteous. Thank you, Dong Baek!
author: Sangwon S.

description: Love the service...however they could've give us more Ban Chan(side dishes) but they only gave us a few...after we finished the first round of side dishes we found out that they accidentally replace one of the side dishes with another one that wasn't in the first round...pretty obvious that they have more variety of them but they chose not to bring it out.
author: Chloe L.

description:
The portions here are pretty huge! We came here for a work lunch and the four of us shared a large portion of seafood pancakes, small portion of army soup casserole, an order of zhajiangmian and an order of fried tofu. We didn't quite finish all the food (a straggling piece of pancake left) and left well satisfied.

I think the seafood pancake is a must order. It's not too soggy like some other places (where it's a bit undercooked) nor does it taste greasy. The rice flour batter is nicely crispy on the edges and tender and chewy in the middle.

We also really liked the zhajiangmian. It's not too salty and had real pieces of pork in there, not that we cared much because the noodles were so delicious. It was al dente and we splurped it up.

The army soup had a good amount of spam and hot dog slices in there and nicely spiced. With the pancake and zhajiangmian hogging most of my attention, I didn't have too much of it, but what I had was great. Wish they put in another packet of ramen noodles in there, too!

The tofu was bathed in a sweet and sour sauce and had a nice crunch. A nice change of pace.

All in all, we really enjoyed the food and the price tag was very affordable. Of course we didn't order any of the more expensive BBQ'ed meats, but we were plenty happy with our carb fest. What can I say, we're just a few peasants at heart that are well satisfied with noodles and spam :).
author: Alice W.

description:
I was a big fan of this place until my last visit. We ordered jjaampong and kimchi pancake.
The jjaampong uses freezer fresh seafood that really smells (the squid was off - ammonia city). The kimchi pancake was soggy (even though we've requested them to overcook it to make it more crispy). Anyways I still remember a time when the mackerel stew was good.
author: Koalie W.

description:
Ordered the traditional staple dishes: kalbi, spicy tofu soup, bibimbap. Everything was just not good. Edible yes, but not what you'd expect with good korean food. I won't be back here. Maybe the empty restaurant at peak dinner time was the first clue?

Compared to the dozens of korean restaurants I've been to in my lifetime and ordering these same staple dishes, this place ranks on the bottom 25%.
author: Grapes T.

description:
Overall:
Pros: Food is good, decent portions
Cons: Expensive ($11-20), bad service, 20% automatic gratuity charge for under 6 people, lots of flies

Did not have the best experience here. Little to no service and an unreasonable 20% automatic gratuity charge with a party of 5 that was not mentioned to us prior nor was it written anywhere on the menu. Our side dishes and water were not replenished.

We came with a party of 5. We were given a big table because we were going to have 6 people, but one of our friends could not make it. After we told the waiter she would not be arriving, he had us get out of our seats and move to a smaller table across from the room. This would have been fine, only we were already seated and given plates and water for over 10 minutes. The restaurant was not crowded at all during this time so I found it a bit unnecessary to move us. 

We received no attention after our food arrived, and had to wave for a good five minutes before they noticed that we wanted the bill. Despite only being a party of five, they included an AUTOMATIC 20% SERVICE CHARGE that was not mentioned to us prior or anywhere on the menu.
author: Christina G.

description: Solid Korean food, good portion sizes, good flavor. And while I find the food good, more importantly, my Korean friends enjoy it. And they probably know a bit more about the subject than I do. It's also right on the 38 bus so it's really easy to get to from either downtown / FiDi or even the avenues :).
author: Sean G.

description:
Came here for lunch.  The servers didn't understand any english, so when I had questions about the menu, they couldn't answer them.  I opted for the beef soup with veggies - it turns out that it's mostly veggies with a tiny amount of shredded beef :(  I was really hoping for real pieces of beef.  My friend really likes this place though so I'll probably give it one more shot and try to order something different.  

Come with a korean friend - maybe that'll help.
author: Janet Z.

description: Not bad for delivery option. I was visiting and craving soup on a cold day and it was prett good. They skimped out on the banchan (side dishes) though. I ordered an app and two entrees and only only set of banchan.
author: Sylvia S.

description:
I used to come here alot before but I ll not gonna comeback anymore.
TobokkI and seafood soup tastes like instant ramen noodle soup. I am sure they are using that.. I could make better than them. I made it togo so I can fix the taste.
author: Seri P.

description: Dong Baek is one of my favorite Korean Restaurant in San Francisco despite the location. I hate that it is located in Leavenworth and there are so many scary homeless around, so be careful when you go there. The ambience and food is five star. I like their Korean Style Chicken, Boo Dae Chi Gae Jeon Gol, Ja-Jang Myun, and Kimchi Fried Rice! It is so mouthwatering and the portion is super big. The Soju is really good (Chum Churum Peach). For the soup that has size S and L option, the portion is super big, so if they said it is for 1 person, it is actually suitable for 2 people. I am not joking, but the portion is really big and worth it! Overall I will reccomend it to everyone!
author: Nesia A.

description: The restaurant service was so bad, they served up to 10 appetizers, but the will look at what ethic you are. Some people they give your more, some people they give less. Not recommended...bad services
author: Angel W.

description: Great food. Usually order their sundae korean sausage) or samgyetang and it never disappoints. The place is really nice too ( has a very asian feel to it) and the service is ok
author: Sui N.

description: Very Americanized. A vast variety of options, and most of them suit the American taste. Don't expect a formal Korean meal. Fine food, the place is sometimes empty sometimes crowded, and definitely worth visiting
author: Daniel L.

description:
Came here on a late Saturday night with my buddies for the second time, and attempted again to order a comforting clean bone soup. Decided on the rice cake beef soup. Again rather disappointed.

One friend ordered the soup with potatoes and beef bones. Both of us felt that the beef tasted not so fresh. Our third companion, a Korean, thought her pricier-than-usual jjajangmyeon delicious though, and I agree!

We all liked the appetizing salad we were presented with.

Next time if we come back I would like to order fried chicken.
author: Vicky J.

description:
Tasty food and friendly service. 

Definitely one of the better Korean restaurants I have tried in SF. 
The staff is extremely welcoming. The restaurant is comfortable and clean. 

Their menu is HUGE, which can sometimes be a bad thing, but the two dishes I tried were pretty good.

The jajang noodles were amazing. Very very tasty. I will probably order these again next time I visit. The kimchi jjiggae was not bad either. 

Recommended!
author: Augusto T.

description:
I unfairly judge Korean restaurants based on their panchan and on how faithfully they replicate the overwhelming meat sweats you get from some of the AYCE Korean joints in SoCal. While Dong Baek loses points on both those criteria, it nonetheless holds a special place in my food gland for fighting the good fight for Korean food in the Tenderloin.

Now, I know that the loin is gentrifying, but when you walk past some of the dealers and homeless folks right outside, you'd be surprised the customer base at Dong Baek stays so strong. Many times that I've eaten here, I'm the only non-Korean, or if there's another outsider, we get to give each other the panicked nod.

Lots of homestyle Korean dishes to be had here, and just one look at the casserole list and you'll understand. This is comfort food, something Mom whips up on Saturday nights when all you have in the fridge is kimchi, hot links, and you're down to bags of ramen. That's where cham pong comes in, and I have a hard time not ordering it each time. Big smokin' bowl of noodles in a spicy red greasy broth, with chunks of squid, oysters, and more onions than your hot date is comfortable macking with. It's a comforting dish that really fills you up on a foggy San Franciscan night, which is perfect since Dong Baek closes late.

The panchan are well-done, but nothing stands out, and they never have fish cake.
author: Kevin L.

description: The best Korean food in Tenderloin. We had a nice time here. Food was delicious, service was so good and attentive. Kinda pricey but it deserved. I will probably come back to explore more food on the menu. Jjang!
author: Joyce V.

description:
I was worried about how authentic this place would be considering it's location and the fact that I received a salad before my bahn chans (side dishes) arrived. 

I was pleasantly surprised at the wide range of dishes they had on the menu. From the all too common dol sot bibimbap to the not too common oyster stew.

After reading several solid reviews for their Jampong (spicy seafood noodle) I decided on it's close cousin Jang Ban Ja jjang (spicy seafood black bean noodle).  Woo! It was good and spicy. Enough heat to Get the nose going and not so spicy that it hurt.  It was just right.  The sauce for the Jang ban jjajang was so good. I was tempted to take it back home and try to recreate but nah...  I'll just be back for more.
author: Gina K.

description:
The food and the service in this place is Amazing! I Love the Spicy Octopus served with noodles. If you can take the heat! Make sure to order this one. parking is a lil err... But where's the fun in that?! Walk! And enjoy Tenderloin Area upclose. And have an action-packed experience and
delicious Korean food for dinner.
author: Sonny M.

description:
Totally in love with this Korean place.
The middle-age women at the restaurant are so friendly and attentive. 
They gave you an as-if-you-were-in-Korea greeting and brought with them right away a glass of water.
It took me some amount of time to decide what to order from the menu tho since it looks fairly expensive.
Still, when the food was served, my jaw literally dropped. 
They serve you 16 small plates of Korean side dish (you can get full from eating only half of them). 
The portion of the food is humongous. I ordered a fish roe soup (small one) and it came with rice. I remember asking the lady if this was a small one and she grinned back while nodded.
The check was around 16ish bucks.
I ended up packing 3/4 of the soup home with all the mini dishes and extra rice, free of charge. 
 Not too expensive considering paying 16 bucks for 2 or more meals eh?
author: Joelle K.

description:
If you're famished, this is the place for you. Walking in, we were greeted with a smile and promptly seated.

Their menu is extensive so it may take you a while to decide from their mouth-watering dishes. In case you're curious, here's a sample menu: http://sanfrancisco.menupages.com/restaurants/dong-baek/menu

On this visit, my BF and I chose:

- Seafood Pancake appetizer - the small version was quite large for us. It was tasty, a bit greasy, came with a dark dipping sauce on the side. I enjoyed it.

- Spicy tofu - it wasn't too spicy and was good. I would probably try another dish next time since there is a variety to choose from.

- Soup - Chicken Cham Pong** chicken and vegetables served with homemade noodles in spicy soup - this hit the spot. We came here on an especially cold night and it warmed us right up. Portion was quite large for the two of us. 

All of this came with traditional Korean banchan - small side dishes that included pickled vegetables, broccoli, fried and marinated potatoes, kimchi, etc. It also came with a starter salad.

Service was a bit slow on our visit even though there weren't many patrons when we arrived for our late dinner, but perhaps it's because it was nearing the holidays and they were a bit short staffed. On the bright side, it was nice to have a leisurely meal.

We were stuffed to the gills and still had a lot left over. The table next to us had the fried chicken which looked mighty tempting. 

Bring your hunger and friends!
author: Cathy K.

description:
The menu tantalizes with much variety. Separate sections for noodles, fish, soups, house specials, etc.; 5 kinds of bibimbap; 8 kinds of -jeon, including 4 that aren't pancakes; Korean-Chinese dishes; lunch specials; prix fixe selections for groups of up to eight people; and even more (no desserts, though) await you within the pages of this menu.

Yet, I'm not sure how many of those pages I'm still anxious to explore. On prior visits I had bibimnaengmyeon, and I might've had bibimbap. The most recent dish I had here put a distance between my expectations / hopes and my taste buds. Maybe I can say it this way: if this restaurant's jjajangmyeon and I were girlfriend and boyfriend, we'd just about be at one of those "It's not you, it's me." scenarios, followed by mutual time off from the relationship. I furthermore don't see long-term potential with this dish and me.

The other Black Day when I ate jjajangmyeon at someone's house, it was thickly sauced and savory. When I ate it at Kukje it was craveworthy; I specifically had it in my mind as I rated KMTR 4 stars. Imagine the house and Kukje jjajangmyeon as seeing your favorite band live - the sounds, the lights, the crowd, the excitement. Then leave the scene and step into an elevator with the muzak version that is this restaurant's jjajangmyeon. I'm not trying to dis. All I'm saying is (and here it is, finally) what's up with the watery jjajang and, most of all, the sweetness? It's like someone took the dish I wanted and threw some spoonfuls of sugar on top while watching "Mary Poppins" in the kitchen. Maybe some people like it this way. Sugary. Watery. Not I.

I liked the noodles though, as well as the serving method of the jjajang and the noodles being in separate bowls. But really, it's like keep that stuff away from my noodles. But I'm not hatin'.

Among our banchan was a more or less cubed potato that tasted like a sweet version of McDonald's fries. You know how some people put fries into their milkshake? Take one back out and eat it. Chew it slowly. Being that but much thicker was what this banchan approached.

After having some "barely there" kimchijeon in Oakland restaurants and on our last visit to Arang, returning to the chewy, springy variety was like going on un-vacation. I think I got hooked on the fall-apart, somewhat (and I use that word with as much emphasis as it can carry) crisp renditions.

An unexpected highlight of our meal was saeujeot (super salty fermented tiny shrimp), which I regard as Korean bagook. We'd never before been served it because, as we were told by our patient and friendly server, it's almost exclusively used in making kimchi rather than standing alone as a condiment. I of course tasted a little bit by itself - yow! I also spread it on stuff like the kimchijeon. Don't be surprised if I start asking for this at restaurants, especially if I find myself with a roguishly sweet dish that needs thwarting.
author: Dan B.

description:
God, this place was good. I had never had true Korean food before and I was so surprised and happy about eating here. Everything I had was delicious, and I would definitely go back. 

The meal is started with some sort of arraignment of tiny dishes filled with things. My dining partner who lived in Korea knew the name of this practice, but I'll confess that I can't remember (or spell it). It was so delicious! I tried a whole bunch of things I might never had had otherwise.

For the meal we shared a seafood pancake which reminded me of the green onion pancakes at Chinese restaurants. This one had a huge bunch of seafood in it and it was delicious. The shrimp were huge and the whole thing was yummy. 

I also had Bibimbap which was one of the most amazing things I have ever eaten, ever. The par cooked egg on the top really made the dish, the ooey-gooeyness was perfect to the stuff cooked in the stone bowl. 

If you're new to Korean food (like I was) I'd have the Bibimbap!
author: Cori N.

description: Service improved even with only two employees working. Food delicious and for four dishes the bill was 74.00 and we had left overs.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
This restaurant was recommended by my Korean friend.   I went there for transitional Ja Jiang Myon at the first time and it didn't disappoint me. It's very delicious and my Korean friend said that it was the most transitional Korean food he had ever tried in S.F.. I went there for many times. This Thursday, I went  there with my friend again. I ordered a kal-bi Tang and  my friend ordered a soft tofu stew. We spent a little bit over $40. It's not cheap but I would say that it's worthy. As many other Korean restaurants, they provide many free side dishes. Moreover, the size of each order are large. One order is already enough for an adult male. 

Besides, the place is clean and beautiful and the staffs are nice.
author: Maggie Z.

description: Really good Korean food you can find in SF... My friend and I enjoyed the dinner here : )
author: Mary C.

description: No clue why this place is not rated higher! HANDS DOWN best Korean food I've had in SF. Nice interior too, feels very traditional! Tastes like the stuff my Korean aunt makes. Prices are a bit higher but you get what you pay for. Very large quantity too! Yeah you have to be a little proactive with getting the service's attention but who cares. They're nice enough and the food rocks. I always get my favorite, the stone pot bi bim bap. They put a much greater variety of veggies in it than what you usually get at a Korean place.
author: C. D.

description: Some of the workers here are so delusional! I ordered the spicy tofu dish. Notice that it's the fourth picture on their Yelp page. The person taking my order asked me about 9 questions about what dish I was talking about. It looks like grilled tofu people with a spicy sauce over it. I sent my roommate to pick up the food and if I would have known they were going to charge me $20 for it I would have ran out their door screaming! I opened the box and there was FOUR. Four uncooked measly little pieces of tofu in there, not grilled or cooked , it look as if they just took it out of box. Then they just slapped about three cups of kimchi on it. I'm so appalled I could cry. Seriously $20. This is an insult Asian food. Honestly I'm so sad  why would you do this to me dong baek? Who do you seriously think would want to eat this.
author: Ludlow S. K.

description:
Okay, not returning to this restaurant and I'm very angry. I'm Korean-American and I'm a disabled veteran so I have a service dog. He's licensed, trained, and very well mannered. I've been to Dong Baek before and eaten inside the restaurant. The owner allowed me in with my service dog one day and welcomed me to return because my dog was so well behaved. I've lived in Korea and I know that many Koreans don't like dogs and even eat them. I hate that stereotype but sometimes stereotypes have a modicum of truth to them. Knowing this, I usually order my food to go. 

This evening I went in to order carry out and the young mohawked Korean guy working tables gave me a hard time about my service dog. He told me I wasn't permitted in to pay my bill. I had to stand at the entrance and when I explained that they weren't permitted to deny me service because of ADA law, he acted dumb and said they couldn't control peoples allergies. Don't lie to me. That's not why you don't want me in your business; you just don't like dogs and don't want to accommodate the disabled because of your social judgment against the disabled (poor) people in your neighborhood. I showed your waiter my dog's service license, registered with the city and state. I gave him a card that had ADA law on it and he didn't even look at it. He handed it back to me and refused to let me walk to the register to pay for my food. No tip for you, buddy.

If you can't treat me like any other customer, I won't ever come back and that upsets me because I liked your restaurant and until now, never had a problem. Now I'm very angry. I'm going to put a sincere effort into letting my large social networks know about my bad experience with your staff. I'm going to tell all of my LGBT, disabled, Korean, dog owner, and able-bodied friends know how terribly I was treated while I gave you my money. Your owner owes an apology. 

And shame on you.
author: Vincent P.

description:
For an area that is lacking in Korean cuisine, discovering Dong Baek is like hitting the jackpot!

The less than raving reviews were from a while ago, most likely before the new management took over. *hint hint* Time for a revisit and update your reviews, Yelpers! 

Their lunch menu is quite extensive and very reasonably priced. I had the JJam Pong which is a spicy seafood soup noodle. It was good! Not as spicy as I would've liked, but I found myself facing an abundance of noodles. My coworker had the Dol Sot Bi Bim Bap, which is the stone pot mixed rice. So fragrant and looked delicious!

Can't forget about the banchan! They gave us 8 or 9 dishes. Also a dish of cheese corn on the house.  Yes, corn with melted cheese. First time seeing and having this dish, it was quite interesting. Nevertheless, always appreciate a free dish!

Highly recommend to those working nearby and are running out of lunch options. The trek is a bit longer than to the usual cluster of restaurants on Larkin. But if you're craving for some Korean food, give this place a try!
author: Marti L.

description: The prices are on the higher end, but they serve good solid Korean food here. I've had many of their dishes including the naeng myun, daeng jang chigae, nakji bokkum.....and all have tasted pretty good. I like coming here when I'm too lazy to drive down to santa clara-ish area for Korean food.
author: Gina P.

description:
The only decent Korean restaurant this side of San Francisco. It's not in the best of neighborhoods but it is definitely worth a trip if you're craving authentic Korean food.

The seafood pancake is great. The monkfish kimchee stew is also pretty good. I can vouch for the kalbi beef as well.

They give plenty of free small bite appetizers too like most real Korean restaurants.
author: Victor W.

description:
What Attracted me here: Cold nights in SF calls for spicy food! I saw that people raves about their big portions for "small" size seafood pancake (my fave!) And kim chee fried rice. 

Parking: I came here around 7pm and there was plenty of free metered parking. Aside from the normal tenderloin residents, it was relatively quiet. But of course, be aware of your surroundings. 

Restaurant ambiance: The restaurant was nicely decorated with plenty of open space. You can tell it was previously a bar, which is now no longer in use by the restaurant. My sister and I unfortunately were seated a weird fence divider and was hard to get their attention. Otherwise the noise level was a bit loud. Not too stuffy from all the steamy foods. 

What we ordered: ($11.95) Small seafood pancake. Came out cut in about standard sized12 pieces, so yes it was huge portions. We also ordered spicy pork ($20.95). Meat was tender, spicy, and juicy without being too greasy. We also ordered Spicy black bean noodles ($12.95). It was HUGE. My sister and I scooped some onto our bowls, and as with any korean meal, you fill up quickly thanks for the banchan they provide too. I looked back at the end of the meal, and it looked like we didn't even touch the noodles.  It was too much and lasted me for two more meals after!
author: Connie C.

description:
I hope there is No Star rating
They have terrible customer services ever had
They never wait for us to pick up menu
They never have patience
They never kind
They force us for tips, even we were eating
She kept saying she needs to go home, what the......I really hate this place 
I will never visit here again
author: Jay L.

description: We had a very great time in the restaurant, the Zhá jiàng noodle tasted so good, we even ordered twice. And the tofu stew was the best choice there, we ordered kimchi tofu , but I love seafood tofu better.
author: Grace Song-En C.

description:
Been here a good amount of times now ever since they came under new management and will stay a loyal customer. Even though the food is pretty pricy, what do you expect out of a restaurant approaching downtown SF? It's in a super sketchy and dirty Tenderloin district but don't let that discourage you. The portions are pretty hefty which means good leftovers for tomorrow! The bbq is probably some of the best I tried in the city so far. It's not the cook it yourself on the table type. They cook it for you in the kitchen which is fine because you can lay back and enjoy your food and avoid the super smoky room. Their other dishes are super bomb as well. The jajangmyun (black bean noodles), kampoogki (sweet wet fried chicken), dukgook (rice cake soup), boodaegeegae (spicy stew) are just among some favorites I get here. The banchan (side dishes) are the best! I was told that all of the banchan is made fresh every single day and it definitely shows. The kimchee is sooooo good! Best I ever had. The variety and amount they give you is amazing.
The service has always been good when I came but I could understand that it can get hectic when it's busy due to the number of people on staff. The owner is my favorite. She's always very nice and diligent when she has served me, but she is retiring which is super sad. Definitely going to miss her. But the rest of the staff are very friendly as well. Some of them, the English might be a little scarce but it's not too shabby. 
For those that come on a late night, I believe they're open everyday until 11PM. Pretty decent selection of beer & wine. American and Korean ones. And who doesn't love Soju? They got that there too!
This place is definitely worth checking out, I've never left disappointed. Just be prepared that parking is a bitch. Super hard to find around that area and be mindful of the street cleaning signs and stuff. 

PS. They don't deliver but you can find a delivery app that will deliver food to you!
author: Andrea M.

description: Stupid service.  A woman she try to give us a bill and charge us 18% for service charge even we are only 5 people.  Moreover she was waiting for the money while we were eating. How shit they give it to us !!
author: Pasakorn S.

description:
Food is pretty good. Service pretty friendly. Though totally partial to Korean speakers. 

We asked to sit by the bar space, as it was not occupied. They said it's not open.

Shortly after, a Korean girl comes in with a posse of three others. Says something to them in Korean and is seated where I asked if we could sit...

Only thing I understood the girl say as she headed over to the bar seating was "gamsamhamnida..." = thank you (formal)

Well. Too bad my Korean is limited to "Beer please," "Hello," "Do you want to die?" And "thank you" of course.

Thanks Korean dramas.

Food was good. Service, once seated, was friendly.

Sure, I'd come back. With Korean friends on peak hours.
author: Tammy H.

description:
Service on a chilly Saturday afternoon was good.  Our food came out in a timely manner, and banchans were refilled without attitude by our hard working server.  I think he was the only one there.  There were also a good number of Korean groups there, so I tried to see what they were having.  I think it was the champong.  It's not a Chinese restaurant, but they also had jajangmyun, and kampong shrimp.  They had a very large menu, in general.  
There were 4 of us, so we got the set menu for 3, which came with an egg drop like soup (again, kind of Chinese), galbi, seafood pajun and kampong shrimp.  We added the spicy squid dish, which was my favorite of the bunch.  I didn't try the pajun but it was large. The kampong shrimp, galbi, and spicy squid were good, but on the sweet side for my taste.  I got the dak gui for Tintin to go, and that was cooked well, without being sweet.  

I can get home cooked Korean food whenever I want, so I don't need to go out for it, but Korean Chinese food is another story.  I would go back to try the champong, and maybe the fried chicken Joshua L. raved about.  Also, it was clean and quiet there, which I always appreciate in the TL.
author: Seong P.

description: My first time having other Korean meal beside having Korean BBQ & I got to try the Dol Sot Bibimbap aka Bibimbap on a hot stoneware & it was delicious especially w/the gochujang paste/sauce. I got to try my cousins meal one had a spicy seafood noodle, the other one had spicy seafood tofu soup & the last one got spicy pork bulgogi & all of the meal were delicious we all enjoy the foods!! We will be coming back for more when we're in Sf & craving for Korean foods!!
author: Bee S.

description:
3.5/5 stars.

This is an authentic Korean place.

The food was authentic and very good here. One of my friends and I both got the jajangmyun with mixed veggies. The portion was huge; we immediately realized we should have shared and even then we might have leftovers. My other friend got the spicy cold noodles and that was very good as well.

Their side dishes selection was pretty big and varied, there were some dishes I had not seen before and that was a treat to try. There were fish cakes, marinated seaweed, beansprouts, kimchi, kimchi radish, etc etc.

This place was clean and the servers were nice old ladies. It was a pleasure to eat here, felt just like a home cooked meal.

The only bad thing I have to say about this place is that the prices were pretty steep. I did not expect to pay close to $20 for jajangmyun, since it is a dish consisting mostly of noodles. Judging from the other reviews, most people agree with me. I think if this place was more reasonably priced, it would definitely get a full 5 stars from me and I would recommend it to my friends and frequent this place.
author: Seliya G.

description: The best Korean restaurant in the city! Taste really good and feels healthy after eating. I tried different things but their bibimba is really good. Small dishes that you get at Korean restaurants, I think theirs taste the best!
author: Kyoko U.

description:
Alright people, I'm going to walk you through exactly how to have the most delicious experience here, but first a few notes: service is alright, could be better but whatev; the Korean music videos playing on the TV are pretty entertaining; the atmosphere is also alright, not super quiet or loud; they take credit cards.

Okay, these are the four things you need to order that will delight whatever company you've brought with you:

Korean-style fried chicken. Delicious. Spicy. Make sure to specify that you want the Korean style though, because I believe they also have a plain version which is not as good.

Short-ribs. They come to the table sizzling on a bed of onions. They're extremely tasty.

Casserole. The one you want is called Boo Dae Chi Gae (sp?). This is like spicy ramen with lots of yummy stuff thrown in. IMO this is seriously the best dish on the menu.

Black bean noodles. If you're not familiar with black bean noodles, head over to Netflix right now and watch "Castaway on the Moon". Go ahead, I'll wait.

Okay, now that you understand the wonders of black bean noodles, you're ready to have some. I like the Ja Jang Myun, but everyone else I know loves the Jang Ban Ja Jang which is also very good.

^^^Best dishes. If you order something else and don't like it, just know that you have brought shame upon your house and must now fall upon your sword.
author: Lindsay N.

description:
It's very difficult to find Korean-style Chinese dishes in any city. This style originated with Chinese chefs establishing restaurants in Korea, and dishes were adapted to Korean tastes. In my opinion, the Korean fried chicken that seems all the rage these days is actually a version of Najo-gi or gampoong-gi. The best place for this style of food is no longer in existence as the owners retired and I have searched for several years for someone to step in to this niche.

At last, this may be it! The black bean noodles and "fried chicken" are nearly spot on. I think there are better places for bulgogi and tofu stew as I found the bulgogi stringy and the stew lacking in daen-jang flavor. Will go back to try other dishes, but I'm happy as long as the Chinese dishes remain. NOTE: these dishes are NOT listed in the full menu provided on the Yelp site.
author: ML R.

description: Amazing food. Had a dinner here and it is one of the best Korean food in town. The service is great and friendly. It's authentic Korean. Seafood small octopus dish was my fav.
author: Jagan B.

description:
Food was okay and server was dishonest. Overpriced for the quality.

Biggest problem is they don't know the difference between chicken white meat and dark meat. I asked the server if the dish really had breast meat and he said yes. It ended up being thigh meat when I opened the order at home.
author: Desiree K.

description:
Pretty good Korean fare - a huge menu that includes everything that you'd expect. I was excited to read that black bean noodles were on the menu so had that with some Chap Chae (beef). 

The servings were huge and between the three of us, were able to get a few little cartons to go. I recommend the noodles. We were the last customers on a Saturday night and service was attentive - besides the salad and the 8+ side dishes, they asked us if we wanted a top up on any of them before we left. The fishcake was great. 

Solid, clean restaurant with lots of seating. Would go back.
author: Lisette P.

description:
nom nom nom nom food.

good food. i like food.

this is a good place to eat food. eat food here. i said so.
author: Yaroslav S.

description:
It's okay. Nice service.    They bring  a bowl of salad to share that is complimentary.   Then all the little dishes, broccoli, kimchee, etc.

I loved the seafood pancake.  The Korean chicken was good and crispy.  The bimimbap was a nice sized portion.  The beef soup was spicy but not that great.   Other than the pancake, I wouldn't order the other items again

We had lunch here today and  there were no other customers.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Oh ... Dong Baek... where to start.. 
Their food is def amazing. I think it is one of the best Korean place in SF. 
5 stars for food 
5 stars for the service
5 stars for the price. 
The best service you could get .. esp, you are the best Grace unnie!  :)

NOTE. This is one of the only place in SF that has Korean style spicy intestines.
author: Yumi K.

description:
Came here after the wait over at cocobang was too long :(

This place is in the TL so uhh be careful!

Food was great as we were all craving korean food. I thought the kimchee fried rice was just ok but I did enjoy the kalbi and the ban chan.

We ordered peach soju and it came in a tea pot which confused us at first! The soju was really light and had that artificial peach flavor to it.

I wouldn't venture here on my own to get korean food because it's pretty sketch but the food is decent :)
author: Christine W.

description:
(See pics)

More of 3.5 stars.

I was craving some spicy Korean food. Thanks to Yelp I found Dong Baek!

Came here and saw mostly Koreans. I know I came to the right place.

The extravagant architecture in the ceiling as well as the side room surprised me. The lighting was a bit off on the white tub and strange brownish them place.

Onto the food, I had my favourite Soon Dubu (soft tofu) with beef. It was fairly spicy that I sweated on my nose and neck. I did expect to have an egg even on other items it specifically mentioned an egg. Maybe I should have asked for it. The pot was fairly delicious and came with rice.

The side dishes were okay.

It's quite inexpensive with the food and a coke it's less than 14 dollars.

Service was very nice. I can only imagine it's a family business from the mother and son looking servers.
author: T L.

description: I thought the food here was meh. I love Korean and want it to be awesome, not meh. Was just not memorable. At all.
author: Andrew K.

description: I would have to say that this is the best Korean restaurant in SF. It had the most authentic tasting dishes compared to other Korean restaurants in SF! Go here if you are in SF, not wanting to drive far, and craving legit Korean food.
author: Janet H.

description:
Authentic Korean food in the Tenderloin. 
Sweet & Spicy meats are very tasty. Ordered the Kal Bi (bbq short ribs) and the Dae Gi Bul Go Ki (bbq/spicy pork). I am told that Jap Chae (sweet potato noodle) is not an easy dish to prepare, but they seem to have perfected theirs. Their kamchan is marinated just right, my favorite for the evening being the seaweed. Also comes with starter salad. The fish cakes weren't too greasy and my first experience with Spicy Squid. Soup was perfect temperature and didn't have to add sauce or condiments for taste.

Got a crash course of Korean traditional customs from my Son's girlfriend. The friendly & attentive staff took amusement with it and helped her out. I think I got most of it down..right. 

We came in hungry, left satisfied, with to~go to spare.
author: Gina Z.

description:
The best Korean food I've had outside Korea. Took me back sniff'
The black bean sauce noodles were so fresh! and the side dishes were aplenty
author: Nea P.

description: I visited this place on one weekday evening. It wasn't so busy so I received a good service. It was very delicious. It is like an authentic Korean style restaurant. The price is good.
author: John C.

description:
Given the few Korean restaurants in the city, I decided to try this place out. The food was OKAY and definitely not as good as I hoped considering the plethora of great Korean restaurants in the Oakland/Berkeley area or Southern California. Below is what I tried out:

- Mul nang myun (cold summer soup) - It was okay. Not amazing, not bad either. The noodles were a little soggy and could have been better.
- Beef tofu stew - the soup was okay. I felt like I've had more better stews that were more flavorful, more punch to it. Nothing special here.

Overall, if you're craving Korean food, I'd try somewhere else in the Inner Richmond/Inner Sunset neighborhoods. If you're lazy, this restaurant will do the trick. I'll admit, I did like the selection of banchan here.
author: Tran N.

description:
Nice, authentic Korean restaurant.
Their fried chicken and Bibimbop are delicious! 
I come here at least once a week.
People are very friendly and nice
author: Mariam T.

description:
My k-lunch today consisted of:

1 spicy bowl of bugeo kongnamul guk
8 dishes of banchan (replenished several times)
3 bowls of rice (upon request)
3 glasses of ice water

The soup was filling and comforting. It had a nice/clean taste, with plenty of pollack, tofu and bean sprouts to fill D-Man's stomach. The place was about 3/4 full when I stepped in. 

Despite some Yelpers saying that service was sub-par, I didn't find this to be the case as the ajimas were very nice and helpful (especially when I kept signaling for more rice/banchans).

Almost all K-restaurants have the LCD Hi-Def Screens playing something Korean-based. They had KBS2 on and was running an encore showing of the historical k-drama Slave Hunters. 

I was really wanting a beer or soju with my meal (I could not since I was "on-duty"). But they had this wall of OB Golden Lager cases stacked high. I kept laughing at the sight. I thought the food was solid 3.25 today, and will probably be going back again to try the other menu items.
author: Derek N.

description:
I went there several times in the past, and this week, and every time it was a bit of disappointment. 
It wasn't that bad, but I felt the food wasn't fresh and not tasty.
I wish there's more Korean restaurant near where I work, but this is as good as I can get. I might try this place again if I really crave for some Korean food.
author: Hyewon C.

description:
Place is legit.  Been craving for Korean and we were supposed to hit our favorite on Geary but they were closed on Monday.  Not located in the best neighborhood so our thought was if we can find a space nearby, it's meant to be...if not, next time.  Obviously, we found one and headed inside.  

It's bright and spacious.  Think there were two other tables and they were all Korean so we felt good about our decision.  

A pretty extensive menu, which makes it hard to decide when you are hungry because everything looks good and you want to order all of them.  We decided with the spicy seafood soup noodle and they spicy squid w/ somen - asked for extra spicy on both.  We got our comp salad with a sweet miso like dressing that was refreshing.  Then came the banchan, a standard selection.  The spicy seafood soup noodle was very good, although not spicy enough.  There were shrimp (two peeled, butterflied w/ tail on), mussels (2 shelled on), squid and sea cucumber (this is a very nice surprise because hubby really likes it and I had a failed attempt trying to make it once).  The noodle was firm and chewy and the soup was good with a nice garlicky flavor.  The spicy squid and somen were both good - mixing them together was a perfect combination.  We took most of it home and enjoyed it over rice at home another night. 

Will definitely return and look forward to trying other dishes.
author: Gloria H.

description:
Been here a few more times since my first review - I must say, this is probably one of the best Korean restaurants in San Francisco. Casseroles, KFC AND Korean BBQ all mixed together for one mighty fine restaurant in the blackened heart of the TL.

Insider Tip: GET the Korean Fried Chicken/Garlic Fried Chicken AND: 

          a) Ask for the sauce on the side (otherwise the chacken is drowning in a very sweet sauce)

          b) Pay the extra $3 for boneless - it will save you a lot of heartache and injury
author: Joshua L.

description: Random Korean restaurant tucked away in the Tenderloin. Service was prompt and the food was pretty good. Banchan was varied and good. I got the spicy stew with tofu and intestines. I really liked this, though I probably should have specified a lower spice level. The small size of the stew was enough food for two people at normal hunger levels. Their appetizers, as with all other Korean restaurants, were a little too pricey to justify on top of a $20 stew. For example, 8 bucks for some dumplings, or 12  bucks for an appetizer portion of seafood pancake. But if you come in a group, you can definitely take advantage of the number of people by ordering different things and sharing.
author: Sherry L.

description:
TIP #1: Excellent service! Your cup will never be empty and your bowl will always be full of rice. 

TIP #2: Great for huge groups! There are a few large tables where large, jolly groups of people were dining together. 

As soon as I stepped foot in Dong Baek, I felt like I was family. The atmosphere is such that it's loud, but with the sound of many conversations between happy people, and busy, but with the bustle of waiters buzzing about, delivering sizzling rice bowls and steaming pots of soup. We sat at a large table for two people; it felt like a dining room table that you'd find at home. 

Since it was a chilly July day in San Francisco, my boyfriend and I both ordered soft tofu soups--he had it with beef, I had it with kimchee. We were served many plates of banchan soon after we ordered. It's always so fun to sample the side dishes, of which Dong Baek had many. Our rice and soups soon arrived, steaming hot and smelling delicious. My soft tofu soup had just the right amount of spiciness. It's very straightforward, comforting Korean food at its finest!

Looking forward to coming back to try some of their other dishes.
author: A.L. H.

description:
In terms of price, it may be a run for your wallet, but the food here is one of the best Korean food I've had so far. 

As for the decor, it feels like you are in a tradition Korean style place. I cannot describe it, but it's like washi wood infused boards separating rooms and dining spaces. There is a tv that displays variety shows. When I went there, they were showing "Happy Together." The table was really nice. 

As for the food, its so delicious, its not like anything I have ever tasted before. I have had pajeon before and japchae, but Dong Baek has a special something to it.  There were some big bold flavors to every single dish. Every item on the menu looked so good, but it took me a while to pick what I wanted. The banchan was so addicting. I love it when Korean restaurants include potatoes and carrots in their banchans. I would say the food is like high quality. 

As for the service, the adjumma there gave us like a free wakame salad or regular salad. I don't know why she did that, but it ws really nice of her. Whenever that adjumma went to our table, she always did it with a smile.

If I had the chance and a whole lot of money to burn, I would eat here often :D
author: Cynthia D.

description: So much good food for the money...can't wait to come back!
author: Monica S.

description:
I was really looking forward to great Korean food and was sorely disappointed at Dong Baek.

We ordered the Korean Wings as an appetizer and they came out second to last which I might have been able to forgive if they had tasted at all like chicken.  Instead they reminded me very much of splintered wood.
The kim chee was passable.
The rice made it to the table near the end of the meal.
The bulgogi was tasty.

I'm a bartender and I usually tip well. Service was slow and I would have likely tipped at least %18 on our marginal service, but a service charge of %20 (INCLUDING TAX) on our party of 5 was added to our bill. This auto gratuity was not indicated on the menu and charging gratuity on tax seems pretty shady.

We also sat next to a dirty table stacked with another family's dishes for the duration of our meal.

In short I will not be recommending Dong Baek to anyone.
author: Jill B.

description: expensive over priced lunch special to go.they don't give you a soup with your short ribs and get like only 3 pieces of meat what kind of lunch special is this I'm still hungry where's the meat!!!
author: Erick W.

description:
Food was ok for Korean BBQ.  I didn't think it was anything special.  
Service was special in a bad way, over 50 min to get our appetizers and food.  I'm sure there are other better restaurant's in the city.
author: Jeff L.

description:
Not in the best part of town, but inside the restaurant is clean and feels korean.  The Korean ladies working there were all very kind and hospitable till we finished our meal even though i stayed way past closing.


Get:
Kim Chee Pancake - Finally a place that does it right and gives you a big portion of this.
Black bean Noodles w/pork- Was good.  Not as heavy as lot of other places but still pretty good.
Pork Spicy Stew - This stuff is usually good everywhere, it was here too.
Kalbi - Standard deliciousness.

Okay: 
Spicy Chicken Gizzards - Huge portion, but I prefer the salt and peppered version of this.
author: Steven F.

description: Not really the best Korean place to go to. The service and the location is not that bad, but the food itself.....I cannot really call this Korean food. I had kimchi pot and tofu something side dish (dubu jorim) and was not satisfied at all. Don't think I would visit again, but I hard jjampong and jjajang are pretty good here.
author: Heidi L.

description:
You know a Korean restaurant is authentic when there are only Koreans seated and when I walked in with my Caucasian friend we got the stares.

Food was very good, and had a decent drinks list. My Korean friends suggested it so I assumed they liked it too.

Don't know why their ratings aren't higher, but maybe because it's too authentic?
author: JET T.

description: Authentic Korean, at a mediocre price. The side dishes were decent, but the restaurant was oddly quiet when we came here (7pm on a tuesday - go figure). The staff was very friendly and Mom like, which reminded me of eating at all my Korean friend's houses when I was a kid. While it doesn't really compare to Korean restaurants in LA, I would come back with a bigger group and take advantage of their family style meals for the quaint atmosphere.
author: Ed D.

description:
My friends and I ate at this restaurant tonight at 7pm. The place had a full house. We were seated quickly and given menus promptly. However, it took them forever to give us the water. Because it look like the place was getting busy, we took advantage of them at our table handing out waters by ordering right then and there. We had three dishes: fried chicken wings, cha cha noodles, and tofu stew.
