After that the servers totally forgot about us. They did not bring us the free appetizers. They kept ignoring our tables and running back and forth for the other tables. I had to ask for the free toppings. That took a while to come too. Once the toppings came the food came right after that. Then, the servers left us alone for the rest of the night. They did not refill the water even though ours were empty due to the extreme spiciness of the tofu stew. I asked the waiter to refill the toppings. He took the empty trays away, but never came back with them. He walked passed our table several times and ensured that other tables were served promptly menus, water, and toppings.

At the end of the meal, we had empty glass bottles and non-replenished toppings. Also they even forgot our beer, which is often the first thing to be given at a meal. However, I do notice that other tables were served much better than us. They were given their beer immediately after being served. Also, we had to ask for boxes to go twice to two different servers until it was brought to us. I don't know if it is the location of the table, which is easily forgotten or what. Overall, the service is absolutely unsatisfying. 

How's the quality of the food? It was just ok. The tofu stew was good but too spicy. The fried chicken was over FRIED, thus the texture was hard. There wasn't much flavor on the chicken because they didn't toss the chicken with the sauce. It was more like dumping the over chicken onto some honey sauce and serve.  I have no comment on the CHA CHA noodles since I didn't eat it. 

I wouldn't recommend this pricey bad service and ok food restaurant.
author: Lily K.

description:
I've long lamented and long used the word "lament" when it came to finding Korean food in San Francisco, like proper, home-style sit-down food. Don't get me wrong, the bar food experience is fine by me, but if you want both, you can find it at Dong Baek. Nestled in what's probably earlobe of the Tenderloin, it might be easy to skip past this place as you're hopping over a rogue turd, but you'd be doing yourself a disservice by doing so (by all means, don't take that as an endorsement for stinky waffle making). 

It seems to have changed hands a number of times. I could be wrong there. But at this point, the food is great and the service is friendly. Some of the edible highlights include some properly juicy kalbi, ja jang myun made with house-made noodles, and meat jun (one of the few places I've ever found this), and woah buddy... ban chan. 

The space is large and has sections mean to accommodate sizable groups and sometimes, there'll be a busload of Koreans in here. At least they get that endorsement. That in and of itself carries its own inconvenience for locals, but whatever. Good for these guys. The downside to that, however, is that it seems difficult to staff for such a large restaurant. The service is still friendly, but on busy nights, can be a little scattered. 

Otherwise, though, it's a nice place to put down some eats, have a Cass, and let the K-pop roll, and think about how awesome it'd be if people stopped using car alarms on main bus routes.
author: Roy M.

description: This is a great place.  I've tried nearly everything on their menu and found it to be pretty good.  The octopus needs a little work.
author: sean d.

description:
My roommate and I were shopping downtown and decided to go eat. We stumbled upon this Korean restaurant and decided to give it a try. We ordered the tofu soup and spicy black bean noodles with seafood. 

Tofu soup was definitely spicy and delicious. It came out pipping hot with a side of rice. The spicy black bean noodles with seafood came in a HUGE portion. You can definitely share this among 2-4 people. It wasn't as spicy as I thought it would be so I asked for extra hot sauce on the side. The black bean sauce was alright compared to the ones I've had in SoCal. It was a little sweeter than what I'm used to. 

I would definitely come back here again, but not for the black bean noodles.
author: Melanie L.

description:
I have been wanting to go back to Dong Baek since the new owners took over. I think they reopened about a month ago. I've been having such a craving for Korean but I promised my coworker I'd wait for her to go. So yesterday we gathered up a small group & went for lunch. If I could, I'd go back again today! 

The lunch menu is very extensive & the prices are reasonable, especially for the amount of food you get. We started with the fish jun, fish slices dipped in egg & fried. Yummy with the dipping sauce. They also brought us an order of pot stickers & salads on the house. Nice! For lunch I got the stone pot bi bim bob. Wow this was quite a dish with tons of fresh veggies, egg, rice, & I added chicken. I struggled to eat it cuz it just would NOT cool down! Everything was cooking in the pot the entire time it was on the table. I burned my mouth over & over cuz I didn't want to slow down. I just loved how the rice got all nice & crunchy on the bottom. Somehow I managed to eat the entire pot! Call me a piggy, I don't mind. 

They even gave us those little plates of unidentifiable side dishes that I love so much. Refills too! 

We split the bill 5 ways & it only came to $15 per person. That's a lot of food for little money. I can't wait to go back & try another dish on their 120-item menu!
author: Erin S.

description:
If I could only use one word to describe Korean food, it would have to be "Red".

Came here for a late dinner with a friend on a Wednesday night. About five minutes after being seated by our server, he came by and asked if we've ordered already. Um, we hadn't even gotten our menus yet! He promptly came back with them and we placed our orders. We were then given one small green salad. Yup, one. Guess we were supposed to share... good thing I'm used to (and have no shame in) eating off other people's plates! (Not exactly a great start to the meal, but I must say that our server was really nice, just a little bumbling at times.) The rest of our banchan (11 of them - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wgr1OpJ1uwuT-wZ4VPJTTA?select=YtlGp-JqT1AikJOPTH5GRA) didn't even come until after our entrées. They were ok, but I was disappointed they didn't offer to refill any of them.

I was looking for something cheap(er) and light so I got the SOFT TOFU STEW with rice (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wgr1OpJ1uwuT-wZ4VPJTTA?select=8fdyyB2IWHC5l08tYLK2ag). This was pretty good, but I've had better. It was spicy yet kinda bland. There was a lot of broth and I felt it could've used more tofu/veggies/meat.

My friend got the CHICKEN KALBI (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wgr1OpJ1uwuT-wZ4VPJTTA?select=0fARJf8n67AMomto6UkvOg). This looked like bloody murder on a plate it was so red - the chicken, zucchini, and onions were saturated with the crimson-hued sauce. It was really tasty though - great balance of spicy and sweet (though just a tad cloying for my taste). Also loved the fact that they use all thigh meat - dark meat kicks white meat's ass! The thick layer of red oil floating on top of the sauce was a little unappetizing though...

All in all, this place was decent, but I'm not sure if I'd come back when there are so many other (cheaper) restaurants in the TL I've yet to try.
author: Steph L.

description: Not bad for last minute Korean food craving.  Came here during Pride SF 2011.  The food was tasty.  Ordered the Tofu Soup (Mild) and Short Ribs (Pretty thick).  Got a free Kim Chee Cake, which was tasty as well.  Id come back for a second round.. Not bad.. not bad at all.
author: Becky U.

description: I recently tried Dong Baek with two friends late on a Tuesday night; we ordered our dishes to be shared family style. My friend suggested the place originally for tofu soup, but since I ordered the hand-pulled noodle soup she ordered the plate of spicy tofu instead. We also got kalbi to share. The hand-pulled noodles seemed to not have enough broth, and the broth was thick and gooey. We asked if we could get more broth, and they ended up recooking the dish so the noodles were soggy. Tofu soup would've been a better choice. The kalbi, tofu appetizer, and banchan were good.
author: Diana B.

description: i appreciate that our server was really nice. however, it is not enough reason for me to go back. the price was a bit pricey for the quality, the bulgogi was dry and there were flies :(
author: Jojo C.

description:
To be perfectly honest, I've never set foot into Dong Baek.  However, while drinking at the Nitecap down the street the other night, the owner of the Nitecap was sweet enough to order some food for me.  I had no idea she had done that for me, but when all kinds of delicious Korean food arrived, I was so impressed!  I realized it's been way too long since I had some really good Korean food and I truly enjoyed it all.  Perhaps it was the alcohol, but the food was so good!

Wonderful place...I will most definitely be ordering more food from them in the future.
author: Roy N.

description:
My friend took me to this place yesterday for dinner because she is so in love with this place. My friend ordered all her favorites which are pork bul go gi, sweet and sour chicken, tofu and seafood soup, and we got a free corn cheese. Everything is so good except the chicken dish was too sweet for me. 

The restaurant is in Tenderion area as you know.... I would rather go there for lunch next time.
author: Natasha Y.

description: Food was authentic, amazing, family style, and affordable! Great place! Highly recommend.
author: Noel N.

description:
I think you can appreciate this place more if you manage expectations. This is a pretty no-frills, comfort food for the Korean soul, kind of place. It's not a fancy kalbi/bulgogi place or impress-a-date place -- it's where I come when I just need some down-home Korean cooking because they do the basics right.

Firstly, it's a pretty good selection of banchan. Which, surprisingly, isn't that easy to find in SF. The yuk-gae-jang is really good (and I usually have enough leftover for a second bowl to take home) and the kimchi-jun (kimchi pancake) is also really good, although it is oily (in a good way, in that delicious fried way). 

The dolsot bibimbap is fine and the soondobu chigae is also pretty good. The mae-woon tang was okay - I've had better but not in the Bay area (yet).

And the best part is that they have so much to choose from, if you like Korean comfort food (stews and soups, mostly).

But, if you're looking for homemade mandoo, not your place. If you want the finest charbroiled kalbi or bulgogi, not the place - the bulgogi was a little on the sweet side but there was a lot of it so I guess it depends on what you're looking for. But if you need a hot, spicy stew or soup, or something warm and comforting in your belly, Korean-style, then I would definitely recommend this place. 

And the service is pretty good - I've never been there when they're packed and they never seem to have more than 2 waitresses so, again, just manage expectations. 

Worst part? Has to be the prices - I mean, it's a supply and demand curve; it's not like the 'Loin is bursting at the seams with Korean places, but I find it's an easy choice to make when I need some Korean.
author: S. P.

description:
I'm in HEA-ven! (said in an Oprah-voice). 

God I love Korean food. And, apparently, Korean Chinese cuisine--as Cham Pong soup is one of my "favorite things."

I knew there HAD to be good Korean food in San Fran, so I set hubby to work on the iPhone to sniff it out. What we learned about Dong Baek I am ever so grateful for. This place helped me work through the final days of a week-long conference in style, health, and comfort in the way that only a super-spicy hot soup can do. 

We had a long night, a long morning, and a long run before we headed in to the restaurant for what was to be breakfast, lunch, AND dinner to us. As 3:30 is an odd time for any of those three meals, we were the only folks in the restaurant save for the team running it. Ambiance was cool. I'm not sure if this is always the case, but there was very loud pop music playing, Korean news on 3 TVs, and some discordant version of Mtv that an adolescent (owner's daughter, perhaps?) was really enjoying. I like this feel in a restaurant. I think it comes from my 4-H days of working in small cramped kitchens to prepare meals for the posse polo riders. There's a sense of community and family that's really pleasant. Like people spend time there even when they're not working. 

Anyhoo, first up for us was the banchan which was plentiful and tasty. Nine or 12 dishes ... I lost track of one of the rows of there. Hubs opted for bibimbop with spicy kimchi instead of ground beef. I, of course, had Cham Pong. The 'bop was beautiful, but I saved my valuable real estate for soup, soup, soup. Unlike Arirang's version (see my earlier review for details): 
http://www.yelp.com/user_details_review_search?userid=LppJHKekgS1MyV29atuj9A&q=cafe+arirang
 
this one had a much lighter broth with less emphasis on the paprika. There was also a greater emphasis on the seafood. The shrimp here were jumbo, there were large scallops, a clam or two, and many, many squids. Not sayin' either recipe is better than the other, mind you, just different.

Midway through our meals, the server brought us out a complimentary order of Korean cheese corn on the house. It was delightfully ooey, gooey, and rich. As one who is not too into sweet things, the golden corn made for a perfect dessert. 

We had a nice conversation with our host upon check out. She was fascinated with where we "learned to eat Korean food," a nod which made me feel proud like a teenage kid. I explained to her that it was in Corvallis, at a now closed tiny restaurant, that I learned to love the spicy. And she taught me that my favorite, blazing soup is a Korean-Chinese dish--not a Korean one. I love how food can bring people together. It's time for more of that in my life. Gom Bae!
author: Dawn C.

description:
This is the weirdest place to have a sit down korean restaurant.  A proper one with all these little banchan, metal spoons, metal chopsticks, and korean hospitality, in the HEEL of the TL.  It was almost a ghost town as I scurried to the front of the store, then ducked inside to escape being tortured for my shoes.  

I baptized Val into the world of Korean food.  Unfortunately she does not like tofu.  Fortunately the store had kimchee chigae with minimal tofu.  It came out in a cauldron.  I got the soft tofu chigae.  My cauldron came out bubbling and spitting like a tar-covered cat.  

There were several types of banchan and I appreciate the variety.  I wish there was more flavor in the soup though.  WHY can't I taste anything?
author: Christina C.

description:
Pretty good Korean food given the central touristy location  albeit more in the Tenderloin area.  We were rewarded with good food and nice service from Korean run restaurant after walking gingerly through a few streets on O'farrell.

Worried a bit on the translation of our allergy issues but felt we ordered safely enough regardless of whether the helpful and friendly waitress fully understood our allergies. 

Short ribs and bulgogi excellent.  Stone pot bim bim bap really nice also.  The pork belly was not as flavorfull as we had hoped but still ok.  Kim chi appetizers were plentiful and flavorfull for the most part.  Lots of food but a bit pricey but may be in line with other Korean restaurants in SF?
author: B W.

description: My 2nd go to Korean restaurant for lunch.  I have to drive here since it isn't walking distance from the office, but service is quick and the food comes out fairly fast.  They have an extensive lunch menu that's definitely worth checking out.
author: Stacey L.

description:
I had a taste of a Korean sausage dish here that practically lit my mouth on fire. I'd count this as a good thing.

Dishes are big, inexpensive and very filling. The garlic noodles with shrimp, in particular, are the epitome of warm buttery comfort food.
author: Anna G.

description:
Visiting San Fran and chose this place because it was not too far from our hotel.  I like Korean food and this place did not disappoint.  Attentive service by friendly Korean ladies.  We ordered the seafood pancake and seafood soon du boo as well as a fish egg roe soup.  The meal came with 10 different side dishes and portions were generous.

The place filled up quickly around 7pm and there were quite a few Asian diners which is a good sign to me!  Will come back next time I'm in town!
author: Lee M.

description:
update 12/20/11:  I dunno what changed, but the sauce is much improved!  Uber yum!
They're back in the game!  I'll report back on dolsot bibimbap next time!


Humph!  It doesn't seem fair to change owners over and over again!  I got all excited last year cuz they started giving all the banchan w/ lunches.  lots and lots.  

but weeks and weeks go by as I practiced my saving money skills.  They up and changed owners again!  They have some banchan (still more than the peeps I loved back several years ago now), but the food is just ok.  

I'm pretty simple (if you can say call spicy food simple), I usually just get a bulgogi chicken or pork.  Big mound of pork covered in the usual red sauce and a big honking heap of rice.  Nice amount of spice.  but the vim and vigor felt gone.  I'll still stop by, but I am looking around for other options for SF korean lunches
author: Rebecca R.

description: Great place for Korean food if you're in the tender-nob area. I love the Jampong and pancake. The banchan are all delicious. A special dish that they sometime offer is their cheese corn, it's a simple dish but oh so delicious!  Main dishes always arrive quickly and the portions are big
author: Connie M.

description:
I'm rather picky with my Korean food, but this place has been an all-time favorite with the girlfriend. Stack some friends on top of that and you can get the course meals for a decent price for what you get. The restaurant is also open pretty late in to the evening and the servers don't stop serving until the doors have been locked and the customers have left. You also get a lot more side dishes than most other places. Seafood pancakes are the best I've tried here. I have no qualms with this place!

The only bad thing I can pick out is the location, but the restaurant itself is quite a lovely experience. If you're looking for the best authentic korean food in San Francisco, come give this place a try.
author: Erik And Sarah Z.

description: My first time to go here. We shared a seafood pancake, tofu soup and beef kalbi. The banchig is free and served before main, they were mediocre. Tofu soup is kinnda too fishy to me, but my bf loves squid in it. The kalbi was great portion for two of us, and delicious. The salad came with kalbi and the orange, sweet dressing was beyond the word!! I asked the server to see if they sold this dressing, but it is a homemade. I could come back for the dressing!!! So sweet and tasty!!
author: Asato T.

description:
How is it this random Korean restaurant is hopping on a Wednesday night - way past dinner hour too - at 9p? I came with RK and EL and we were surprised at the large groups chowing down on homey Korean cuisine. We took it as a good sign.

We ordered basics:

Appetizer: Hae Mul Pajeon ($10.95 for small) - this is mixed seafood pancake with green onions. The small was pretty sizable. Maybe not the tastiest but I liked the consistency - right amount of crispiness on the edges and not watery mushy like some places. Could use more seafood but not bad. Caught some shrimp and calamari and imitation crab meat here and there.

Mains to Share:
- Dol Sot Bibimbap ($12.50 or less) - pretty basic. Not outstanding. Maybe because we didn't spread the rice around the stone pot as my usual method. It was beyond my reach.
- Za Zang Myun ($7.50) - noodles were just right - QQ - al dente - however you want to state it, they tasted fresh and springy. And it came with lots of black bean sauce. Only thing I would add is sprouts or some veggies.

Banchan: I counted 1 salad bowl (for the table) + 8 varieties of small dishes but they give you very little of it in each dish - fried potato, kim chee cabbage, spicy cucumber, spicy daikon chunks, sprouts, seaweed, shredded tempura skin, and steamed broccoli. They didn't offer to refill though I think they would have if we asked. Not impressive banchan though.

Service was ok - they were short staffed for an unexpectedly busy night.

I'd come back for the noodles. Extensive menu is definitely an attraction for future occasions.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Was craving some Korean food, and this was the nearest place that I found in the Tenderloin.

Ended up ordering the Ja Jjang Myun (noodles with black bean sauce), which was delicious! The noodles were cooked just right, and the portion was gigantic (especially after eating the banchan). I do wish that they had a better selection of banchan though (kimchi, sprouts, potato, tempura, daikon) as it was good but not anything special.

Their menu looked pretty extensive though, so I'll definitely be back to try out some of their other dishes.

The service is really great, and the Korean ladies are incredibly sweet.
author: Jonathan H.

description:
Korean friends brought me here the first time, I kept coming bringing every of my friends visiting the city. You have to dare walking through a bit of the Tenderloin to get there, but it worths the experience. Im frustrated I can't remember the name of my favorite dish.. (it's a noodle dish with black beens sauce and potatoes).
Service is really nice, and I was glad they recognized my caucasian face the second or third time I came.. They even offered a tasty appetizer. 

Thanks Dong Baek!
author: Alice G.

description: Pretty good Korean food restaraunt with fast service and clean environment. Only thing I'd say was for the couple times I've been here, the food was always served too hot! Other than that, awesome food!
author: David S.

description:
As far as authentic Korean food goes in the city, this place is pretty good. Lots of delicious banchan (side dishes) that included two different types of kimchi, potatoes covered in sweet yummilicious sauce, odeng (fish cake), bean sprouts and etc. 

My friend and I went there after a few beers and made the amateur mistake of filling up on the banchan. When our main dishes arrived, we were like stuffed little piggies. We pulled it together though and proceeded to dig into the soft tofu soup and seafood pancake.

The gluttony was completely worth it. Oh man was the stew yummy! Full of flavor and spicy! I would definitely go back for the stew.

As for the service, it was what you would expect from a busy Korean resto. Not great but not terrible. 

All in all, this was a great experience even if it is located in the Tenderloin.
author: Dianna S.

description:
it was 10pm, i didn't feel like going all the way to richmond or sunset to satisfy my korean food craving. Dong baek was located right across the street where i'm staying, so i decided to give it a try.
First impression: the banchan.
There was a massive variety of banchan, like 10 side dishes and they were all well done. Sweet potatoes, seaweed salad, kimchi and other stuff that i can't remember, but i was very impressed. The veg salad was fresh and super tasty with a delicious, idk, cheese, spicy, sauce on top, yummy. 
The ladies were welcoming and attentive.
Ordered the spicy black bean noodles and seafood pancake. I was put off at first cuz of the prices, a tad higher than what i often have. However the food did not disappoint. Delicious. Nothing really spectacular, but they were decent and solid. Although i regret ordering them cuz the portions are huuuggee. i managed to eat half of it and then gave up and got them take-out. I think i was still full til the following morning. So yall better come here with friends, or just be really hungry.
author: Daniel N.

description:
I passed by this place a ton of times while coming home on the 38 Muni -- I passed it again last night, so I looked it up on Yelp, read about their awesome lunch specials ($10 on average) and made plans to eat there for lunch today on my holiday day off :).  

So happy I did this!!  It's awesome first of all because it's close to my place (please take care to navigate here through the dicey Tenderloin but it can be done).  When I first try a Korean restaurant, I start with the chicken bul go ki as a good base and go from there.  I happily watched as the waitress placed all the little vegetable dishes in front me first - kimchee, bean sprouts, pickled vegetables, etc. - loved it already!  :)  Plus, the lunch special came with seaweed soup with a slight taste of yummy sesame - very comforting!  That was slurped up and gone in no time!

And the chicken bul go ki came out on a hot platter (ouch, don't touch!) in the shape of a cow - cute!  And it was tasty -- definite good start.  I couldn't finish my chicken, but I packed it up and it's going to make yummy leftovers later!  :)  

Dong Baek is a homey place with traditional Korean dark wood accents.  The service was good, quick and checked on me only when I felt it was needed as I was too busy chowing down to even look up most of the time.  Ha!  I will definitely be back!!

My bill+tax+tip = $11 (lunch)
author: Maile N.

description: Umm....I've only been here once. The food was so-so. Nothing special to me. The service was also very bad. It impressed me most unfavorably.
author: Kelly C.

description:
I came here with high hopes of getting Meat Jun, and low and behold they have it! However it was the most expensive appetizer at 14.95. I held my breath and tried it anyways. 

I was sorely disappointed when it came out as small pieces covering half our plate with the other half being a pile of salad. smooth move Dong Baek smooth move. It tasted fine but definitely wasnt worth the Value. Overpriced and had some fruit flies (gnats) flying around us. the rest is sub-par korean foods, and standard multiple side dishes filled with pickled everything. I wont eat here again.
author: todd p.

description:
Not the best Korean food, but definitely NOT the worst either.  The price is reasonable, the servers were pleasant and the food was decent.

I ordered the Dol Sot Bi Bim Bap, which got completely cold while I ran my mouth telling stories to my friend.   Yet, the food was delicious.  

The potsticker appetizers that we shared fell apart :'(.

All in all, we had 2 dishes, 1 appetizer for $39 (incl tax, sans tip).

Parking here is a bit of a pain.
author: Hiromi N.

description: A good option for authentic Korean food. The restaurant atmosphere is nothing special (there's some odd lighting from energy-saver bulbs that doesn't help), but the service is friendly, it's easy to get a table (even on a Saturday evening) and the variety of selections on the menu is pretty wide.
author: Rob R.

description:
LEGIT.  The short ribs are amazing!  A little pricy for the area but I guess the quality justifies it.

Sidenote: I'm not a fan of most of the 'side dishes', but that's just me.
author: Ibraheem A.

description:
So we're tried of trekking out to the Richmond from SOMA/Potrero for Korean food. I don't care what anyone says SO in Soma is not Korean. So doing a little Yelp research we find this place and we decide to take the plunge.

When we first walked in we're surprised that it's bigger than expected and actually feels like an actual Korean restaurant versus a Soju spot that serves food so +1 for that.

So the good points:
They have a really full menu. They even have some of the Korean/Chinese dishes like jah jahng mien (black bean sauce noodles) but they also offer the full range of bbq'd meats and stews. They also bring out "banchan" all the sides you get with a full Korean meal.

The negative points:
Two servers for like 20 tables. They're super nice but when it's busy there is no way to handle that many tables and bus them as well. If they just added one bus boy that would give them some relief to be able to at least check on you once. Basically I watched people get up and ask for things or you have to almost grab the waiter as he/she runs by to ask for something. BUT they're running around so much they forget so you have to repeat this a good 5 times.

The food: Most of the food was good. We order Kal Bi (short ribs) which was good. Pah Jun (Korean green onion and seafood pancake) and the Jah Jahng Mien. A lot of food yes. The main dishes were good. Not spectacular but good enough if we don't want a long commute to get some Korean. The banchan however, we noticed was not as fresh. Don't get me wrong, it's mostly pickled vegetables so there are various stages of sour and in a Korean home its all good when it gets sour but at a restaurant you're pretty much getting served some old banchan. Not all of it was like that but a couple of the dishes were.


So I'm torn about this place. I wanted it to be good really bad and the food was decent but they are just severely understaffed. We literally were never checked on. Anytime we needed anything we had to almost grab the server physically since they're so busy. Just unfortunate that is the case but knowing that I'd go back in a pinch.
author: Hyung L.

description: Great authentic korean dishes. Generous portions. Probably top 3 korean food restaurants east of van ness.
author: Alex M.

description:
In general, SF has lacked a robust Korean food scene.  My Korean friends end up going to Oakland, San Jose and even LA.  No need to do that anymore with Dong Baek in the house!  I even made a video review featuring my family and very picky Korean mother-in-law at Dong Baek last Saturday.  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vk9_qKNkIsw.

I was shocked at how extensive the menu is.  There's something for everyone in my (picky) family -- my youngest son likes Kalbi, my Korean-American husband craves Ja Jang Myun (homemade noodles with pork and black bean sauce) and I wanted the Stone Bi Bim Bop.  Big kudos on all the main dishes -- all tasty and authentic.  Same quality as you can get in Seoul (really.  I just spent two weeks there on a family vacation).

The kimchee, itself wasn't that impressive.  It lacked the depth and acidity and tang that I was looking for.  Then again -- no one makes kimchee like my mother-in-law.  Also -- thumbs down on the steamed pot stickers because they lacked flavor.  

My family will definitely be going back.  I want to try the  Mul Nang Myun (Cold buckwheat noodle soup) and Kal-bi Tang (beef short-rib soup).  The service was good despite that it seemed understaffed -- one guy running around a little frantic.  He came whenever we called him over, which was a lot.  

The neighborhood feels a bit sketchy so stay alert.  It's only a few blocks East of Tommy's Joynt.  We got super lucky to get a parking spot on the same block -- I don't expect that to happen again.
author: Sabrina G.

description: This place just makes me happy. The vegetarian section is great and everything comes looking amazing. I love the onion pancake and the black bean noodles. They are serious. I come with the same friend everytime, order way too much food as the portions are quite generous, and leave perfectly content and stoked for left overs.
author: Nathan T.

description: A group of 6 of us went to this place for dinner. Service was great and very accommodating. Portion sizes are large so you probably can share dishes if you are in a group. We ordered six dishes and only one dish wasn't good. But then again it was not a recommendation. I had the pork bulgogi, very good. Other dishes we tried were spicy stir fried intestine (very spicy but very good), kalbi, stir fried squid and pork. All these dishes were good. The banchan they brought out was decent. Great experience!
author: Seema K.

description: I went to Korean restaurant for the first time in SF. I tried the lunch menu of soft tofu stew $8.99 + tax. It's probably the cheapest item in the menu as Korean food is not cheap. It was fine, a little bland for my taste but people who prefer less tasty would enjoy this dish being prepared this way. The bachan that were served consist of very small portions of 3 different kinds of kimchi, cucumber, bean sprout, seaweed, but no egg or seafood like anchovy or raw squid. Probably it is cheap meal that they decided to give all vegetables. As always, Korean restaurants are more expensive than others because they gave complimentary appetizers. They did not accept Amex.
author: Jenni L.

description: We were seated quickly but the wait service is not particularly pleasant or attentive.  Had to wait for water, more side dishes (one set for 5 people), and togo boxes for our soup/stews.  The portions are good and the price is about $10 per stew/soup.  But the soondae (pig intestine) soup was the exact same spicy, peppery orange soup as the beef stew my other two friends got.  Also, there were more organic, strange body parts than the normal soondae pieces in the soup.  The side dishes are pretty good.  Probably would not come back unless I was in the area and craving Korean food.  South Bay Korean food is much better!
author: Chris L.

description: Among Korean restaurant in SF, this place can be placed at near 90 percentile. But as  a Korean person I rank the food quite about 65 percentile at best. As long as you want to taste different food at SFO, I would recommend Dong Bak ( Carmellia in English ). If you are Korean and must have a Korean food with Soju, go there and you will be ok. If you are looking for a decent food with a good service and atmosphere, think twice. My rating would be only two stars.
author: Youngsoo R.

description:
My first Korean experience. And I'm deathly allergic to sesame. Seeds and oil. So, ordering for myself was a little tough. 

We chose this place because you do not cook your own food. Everything is done in the kitchen so when you leave you won't smell like Korean food. Which is a plus when you're about to be in a small room filled with people. 

I was able to eat the shrimp and veggie tempura, the corn and cheese free appetizer, and the seafood pancake. I LOVE the Asian pancake thing. Beef pancake, chive pancake, turnip cake, seafood pancake... I love them all. Everything I had was good. My dining companions liked all the sesame stuff too. The hot pot looked great. I love crispy rice, but it had sesame in it. The bip bam boo (uhhh, i think it's called that) I heard was delicious. It was the beef without the bone. 

We got tons of free appetizers, boiled pot stickers, corn and cheese, miso soup, and some others. So order light cause you'll end up with way too much food! And if they don't bring you extra food, then you can just order more if you're still hungry. 

All in all, it's good food, hard to special order (they put sesame seeds on some stuff we asked for none - granted Korean is probably the hardest to order with a sesame allergy, so I can't complain), great service, you won't smell, a little pricier than I expected but dishes were very big. I liked it all, and if nearby and with people craving Korean, I'll easily come back, but I won't be begging to come back.
author: Ali R.

description:
My first adventure with Korean food!

I liked everything we got - of the things we ordered:
the seafood and chive pancake was great
the hot pot was good but a closing in on too spicy for me
the beef (no bone) was very good even though it looks so unappetizing.
Of the freebies:
the corn with cheese thing was good (how can it not be?)
the boiled pot stickers - yum
salad, fine
tea, great
soup, good

* they cook in the back here, not at your table!
I can't wait to try Korean again!
author: Jessica L.

description:
Average service, Average food.

I like Dong Baek much better than Cocobang. 
I wish they had a grille at each table to cook meat though...

Their lunch special is $7-9.  I think the place is OK for lunch.  Their side dishes tasted good.
author: Chie J.

description:
The food is very whitey; the Korean food purist would find it greasy and not salty enough. But, you do get a lot of side dishes so its a good place to introduce your white rice friends to the Korean food.

That being said, the price isn't too bad with most dishes around the 10 dollar range, and food is prepared quick. It does tend to get packed during the dinner rush, and on weekdays they only have 2 waiter/waitresses for 20 tables!!
author: Eugene L.

description: Good Korean restaurant to go to in the tenderloin. The prices are pretty expensive. The Cham pong bob and the jang ban ja jang dishes are good. Service is friendly and ok. Wait times are sometimes long depending on what you order. Also refills and requests take a long time when it gets busy. Overall i like the taste of their korean food compared to others in the area, but their prices raised this year; so i don't go here often as i used to.
author: Collin L.

description: Their jjajang myun or black bean noodles was one of the best I ever had in this city actually. Many of their soups and stews are good as well as they arrive piping hot and flavorful.
author: dublin a.

description:
A group of friends and I dined at this Korean restaurant and we were all sorely disappointed.  A couple of my friends ordered noodles w/ seafood and black bean sauce.  Upon arriving, the dish looked utterly unappetizing.  It was described by one as a plate doused in watery mud.  Another friend commented that they only had 3 shrimps in the entire plate.

I ordered the Bi Bim Bop and was not very enthused about the dish.  It was cold, the rice was cold and the flavors were lacking.  

For the tenderloin, the place is clean, service was very attentive, but the dishes were sub par.
author: Khristian B.

description:
This is a no-frills place, but well worth a visit.  If you're not familiar with the Tenderloin, be aware that you will have to side step some, uh, interesting people on the way to Dong Baek.

I love the Korean restaurants that give you all those little bowls of condiments.  Sometimes, I don't know what I'm eating, but I almost always love it.  The pickled daikon radish was my favorite.  Among the thing we ordered, the Bibim Bap and the beef with clear noodles were the tastiest.  My pork bul gogi was rather fatty, so I wouldn't get it again.  We did not have the corn and cheese thing that other Yelpers are referring to, and I'm really sad about that.  Corn + cheese sounds like a match made in heaven!

The prices and service here are excellent.  I love their tea, too.
author: Raina S.

description:
Ahn Young Ha Seh Yo! ("Hello" in Korean)

I am thrilled that there is a good Korean joint by my place. I live a block away from here and in the 1.5 years I've lived downtown the only Korean restaurant I've gone to is Coco Bang (which has a couple of really good dishes of its own but otherwise very nominal Korean food). My friend had told me about this place and she said it was "ok", and since my friend is also Korean and from Korea Town (LA) I took her word for it. However this was before the management changed and so I decided to give this place a shot. 

Here's a tip: You could always judge a Korean restaurant by the quality of its ban chan (small side dishes) and kimchi. Dong Baek does both well. The ban chan was fresh, tasty, and there was a good variety. Now it's not the best ban chan I've had nor the widest assortment, but overall it was good. The kimchi was also good, but a bit too vinegary for my own taste however others may enjoy that. Their gak duki (raddish kimchi) was superb! I'm a big gak duki fan not only because its delicious but because its also fun to say. GAK-Duki!

I had the dol sot bi bim bap (hot stone pot rice with assorted veggies and beef) and the soon do bu ji gae (hot spicy tofu soup). I would give the bi bim bap 5 stars and the soon do bu 4 stars. You definitely can't go wrong with their dol sot bi bim bap though and if its your first time trying Korean food I'd probably stick with that or some kind of bbq (kal-bi, bul-gogi). 

The service was fast and friendly, and all in all I really enjoyed my meal here. If you're in the downtown area and craving Korean then I recommend checking this place out. It's not the best I've ever had, but it more than satisfies the Korean craving. I'll definitely be back.
author: Richard K.

description: Food was mediocre.  This restaurant was in a bad part of San Francisco which makes it so you have to either drive there or take a taxi back to your hotel.  I took food togo for a party of 7.  They seemed to skimp us on the food because the last time I went there I remember having more portions and the food actually being good.  I also do not remember the bill being so high for each dish.  Will try this place one more time...
author: Brian L.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco, and the lunch menu is a major bargain. 

The luncheon Bi-Bim-Bap is a steal in expensive San Francisco - a huge bowl of rice with veggies, meat, and a perfectly cooked egg, surrounded by eight bowls of various kinds of Korean pickles and condiments. Service was excellent - efficient and attentive. My Bi-Bim-Bap arrived sizzling hot it its stone container. 

If you eat Dong Baek's Bi-Bim-Bap for lunch, you're not going to have room for dinner later that day, and you'll be full of healthy, good-tasting food.
author: Mary F.

description:
My sister took  me here for dinner tonight.  It was sooooo good! We each had the Soft Tofu stew, and shared a vegetarian, japchae. I really liked the tea, too. 

Our server was very pleasant.  As we looked around, we were the only non korean people dining there. Must be good, right? 

 We discoverd this place strolling through the neighborhood one day.  Haha, the shady neighborhood.  Funny, some of the best restaurants are found in the Tenderloin.  

We work in the union square area, and stoked to find an excellent korean restaurant, close to work!
author: Marvella W.

description: This place is pretty good for authentic Korean food.  My friend and I came on a Thursday night and seem to have been the only non Koreans eating here, which is a good sign.  I love anything spicy and I'm pretty adventurous in trying out new foods.  The menu is extensive with many many choices, pages and pages of choices, ranging from common dishes like bibimbap and japchae to lesser known dishes for the more adventurous diner.  There were so many choices it took us forever to decide on what to order.  We ended up getting the seafood pancake, daeji bulgogi, and golbaengee muchim, all of which were delicious and spicy hot, and with 10 different varieties of delicious banchan.  The portions were very generous and the prices are reasonable.  Customer service is great and attentive.  I highly recommend this place!
author: P.J. D.

description: Great food, worth braving the Tenderloin @ night.
author: Joe G.

description:
Delicious, a must-try for Korean food in San Francisco. Seafood pancake and kimchi cchi-gae were excellent. 

What I also like is that they have Japanese beer and Korean soju. I love my Korean food, but sorry, Japanese beer over Korean beer any day!!
author: J K.

description:
Feeling the pull of my roots, I went in search of a Korean restaurant in walking distance from Union Square, and found Dong Baek. 

The service was great... in fact, in addition to the banchan, we received a free salad (it's the thought that counts, right?) and steamed dumplings. But the food overall was average. 

The soon dooboo chigae was not good at all... usually one of my favorite dishes on a cold night, I found the taste extremely disappointing. Thank goodness for the dol sot bibim bap (rice and veggies cooked in a stone pot with pepper paste), which was quite tasty.

The baek seju didn't hurt either.

Don't think I'll be headed back to this restaurant the next time I visit San Fran, but overall, it was good enough to satisfy the craving.
author: Doris P.

description: A pretty standard korean restaurant, nothing great but nothing bad.  The restaurant, food, and ambiance is pretty authentic (they speak korean, the menu is in korean, and there's a TV going on with korean news on it).  We got a haemul pajeon to share, which was tasty.  I got the soon dae guk, which was not that great since I only got about four pieces of soon dae in it.  My friends got the dol sot bibim bap, the jajang myun, and the kimchi jigae, all of which were tasty.  They did forget to put in the kimchi jigae order, but were very apologetic about it.  Overall, it was a good experience save for my soon dae guk, but I know not to get that again.
author: Chich S.

description: I have been here a few times because of the delicious clay pot dishes they have. The meal is always enjoyable and the dim sum is a nice addition. Highly recommend this place is an affordable option for korean food in the city
author: G T.

description:
meh...the food was overpriced ($14 for kimchi bookumbop?!)

service was fine.

i can make better kimchi bookumbop at home.  DB's was pretty bland.

the banchan was pretty standard.

they serve adult beverages.
author: Sally T.

description:
Let's first get rid of the minuscule negatives out of the way

1) Korean food is known for side dishes, and will refill quickly. They don't give you enough and it's kind of a pain to ask.
2) slow service
3) if you get the kalbi- its really good but i don't thikn its worth 20 dollars

Positives:
1) Food is realllllllllllly reallly deliicioussssssss
the squid is really tender, not chewy at all! you can actually swallow it like regular meat

seafood pancake- soooooooooooooo delicious and crunchy!

i've been there 3 times , all with huge groups of people so I've tried a lot and nothings disappointed me yet.

the food might seem expensive at glance but the servings are huge and if youre not a huge gluttonn, sharing is recommended


yeah one big ol positive!
author: Lily T.

description:
My soup tasted like instant soup, no depth what's so ever.
My friend soup tasted better which was $15. Mine was $10.
Great namul thought. so 1 star for that.

No service what's so ever either.
author: Green Mango Y.

description:
Came here because my friend lives next door and said it was amazing.....well....I now have to question their taste in food.....
Not that the food here was bad, it just wasn't "wowing"... I had #1, the short ribs, which were good, greasy and on the fatty side...but the dish comes with seaweed soup and an assortment of pickled things....now,maybe I'm only a fan of pickled pickles....but...bleh....
Thought it was also pricey for what it was.....probly won't be back
author: Bianca L.

description:
There is a girl I know, lets call her January. She epitomizes everything which is good about life in SF. Fun, Crazy, and Beautiful. She is an amazing person. 

We had dinner here. I thought I was charming: favorite stories about her family, memories about past relationships, music stuff.

I kissed her when we were walking down the street.  Best Kiss ever!!!!!  I think so anyway...

The Korean food is pretty  good. 

4 stars.
author: John T.

description: Large portions on the Jajangmyeon. I enjoyed it but some may find it too sweet. Their casserole good, but not too unique. Spicy ricecakes were pretty good as well. The small side dishes were average.
author: Gianni C.

description:
I am tired of being the 'ugly friend'. Seriously guys, if you're gonna treat me like that, at least do it discreetly. That's how I felt when I dined here with a female friend of mine and all the waiters at that time were guys. They re-filled my friend's glass but not mine. They asked how's everything to my friend, but not to me. Sigh...

Anyway, I do like their ginseng soup dishes (sam gye tang? or kalbi tang?). It's really good when it's cold outside and you're tired from walking in union square. The walk there is a bit scary, but I used to live just half a block away so I'm used to it.

Also, I assume this place is authentic because often times I see a tour bus full of korean tourists double parking right in front of the restaurant. That's a good enough indicator of how authentic the place is, no?
author: Ari C.

description:
came in here noonish and only saw 2 elderly  korean ladies busy chatting and eating. i knew then to avoid ordering any meat dishes that may be past their prime.

the soon tofu chi gae lunch special(7.25)  was 1/2 the size of a regular order. accompanying the mostly meatless, tofu, zuchinned broth was 7 banchan, fresh but not spectacular.. 

beyond getting the order, bringing the tea, and bringing the soon tofu, the waitress was nowhere to be seen. maybe she's playing some kind of card game in the kitchen with the kitchen staff. servicing the customers certainly wasn't her priority,.

dessert-melon gum
author: Victor G.

description:
I'd say this is the best Korean restaurant within the Downtown shopping vicinity. It's a scary walk from Downtown Union Square to the TL, but it's worth it if you drive out to Brothers on Geary, Japantown or some other Korean restaurant. Meats are tender, the setup and ambiance are comfortable, but service is almost non-existant if you end up sitting away from the waitresses' sight. This place is nice for larger groups because they have isolated tables within small rooms. I recommend coming here for lunch because they have lunch prices. For lunch, I give 4 stars just because it's cheaper.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
To echo previous reviewers, service here isn't much, unless my friend's friend Jae is here (funny young Korean guy w/ glasses and a perpetual smile)

But honestly... who the hell cares?  The food here is plentiful and is SOOOO good.  My fellow vegheads, even though the menu is dominated by meat, the waiters and waitresses will accommodate you if you ask them to hold the meat/any animal products.  Their Chap Chae (yummy garlicky glass noodles) made vegetarian almost made me cry, it was so good!  And of course the little pickle dishes are mostly vegetarian (watch out for the fishy ones)... go kimchee!  They also make really good vegetable pancakes, kind of like the crispy ones that you see in Chinese restaurants but these are thin and chewy, almost crepe-like.  Everything comes in very generous portions - I was stuffed less than halfway through the meal.

For the die-hard meat eaters, I've been told by my fellow diners (two of them from Seoul) that the pork bulgogi and the kal-bi is as close as you'll get to the same dishes from their motherland. No surprise though, there's tons of native Korean diners here, so I take that as testament of the restaurant's authenticity

Ambiance... well again there's loud, angry-sounding Korean conversation, mostly between men, all around you, but I don't mind.  This is also another secret spot in the TL, so well... not so friendly of a neighborhood at night, but I don't mind.  But then again, I tend to be adventurous.
author: Catherine C.

description:
Dong Baek has the right idea although it's not always 100%. The food, while pretty good, isn't top-notch. It'd great home-style cooking served restaurant style (if that makes sense). Service is quite good, except for this one time I asked the lady for more kimchi and she told me to finish my plate first. That was pretty bitchy, and I'm not her kid, and I don't want to be spoken to that way. All this aside, the little side dishes, while the variety changes, are pretty solid and the portions are quite enormous. This place is a little expensive compared with some establishments in Oakland or the Sunset. I had a chance to try out some of their stews, casseroles, braises, as well as some popular diner items like ddeoukbokki and savory pancakes, as well as their koreanized Chinese menu, which I found to be decent. If not top notch, the new management has definitely revamped dong-baek into a reliable go-to place for an authentic Korean experience in the heart of SF's tenderloin. I recommend that you try this place out and ignore the drab "decor" and exterior of the unfortunate location.

My favorites include the soft tofu stew (beef), the stir-fried kimchi/tofu, pork fried rice, and the braised short ribs (with large potato chunks). I hate the serving vessels they use; all the plates and bowls are cheap and plastic, but a lot of koreans don't have nice china, so I'll get over that. Service is really quick, and you get complimentary tea - nothing gourmet but 100% Korean.
author: Y K.

description:
if you don't have the good fortune of having my mom to cook korean food for you, i recommend this place to you.

disclaimer: i'm korean, and no restaurant ever has compared to my mom's home cooking (or any of my aunts' cooking).

however, this place is acceptable.  which for anyone who's not me means it's at least 3-4 star. ;)

the food is good.  pickled dishes are well spiced and seasoned.  the fresh veggies are actually fresh (as opposed to tired and limp).  they don't use too much sugar or sesame oil here - for some reason many korean restaurants in the states overload everything with sugar and sesame oil.

my non-korean friend enjoyed the dolsot bibimbap (stone bowl mixed rice) and the gagangmyun (black bean paste noodle).  service was efficient and quick. 

the prices match the portions.  but for me the portions are a bit large.  take home is not a problem though.
author: Peter K.

description:
I came here tonight for dinner because my friend frequently walks past and wanted to check it out. Seeing that it got pretty decent reviews we were quite excited. The area is super sketch. I was walking from union square direction over and I was quite nervous. but then again I hardly come to the tenderloin. I was quite surprised when I saw the restaurant tho! It stood out cuz it looked quite fancy considering the location! 

When I opened the menu, the first thing I noticed was that they serve Gam Ja Tang. I find that it's pretty tough to find korean restaurants that serve gam ja tang in SF. We ordered that and a beef jap chae. They first served us a salad. It was not bad. The dressing was pretty yummy but after we ate the first layer with the dressing it wasn't so appealing anymore. Then they brought the mini appetizers. mmm. I was quite impressed with the variety. There must have been over 12 types including 3 different types of kimchi ! :) The jap chae was OK. nothing too special. The gam ja tang threw me off because it was yellow instead of the usual orangy red. But nonetheless, it was still pretty tasty. They put alot of veggie in it. The pork was ok. a little fatty. 

It was quite busy for a Thursday night I thought. The price is average.. not cheap considering the area. But overall, I would come again :)

i was going to give 4 stars. then i remembered there was a ton of flies that we had to keep swatting.
author: S H.

description:
loved the place
it is one of the few Korean restaurant that make a good yokijang which is my fav dish
we ordered 1 bibimbap 
1 yokijang
2 soft drinks
we paid around 35$ which is good
the serves was good and the food was delicious
i recommend this place
author: Nada A.

description: This is one of my "go-to" places.  The staff are always friendly and surprisingly the girl always remembers me and says "long time no see". Have eaten lunch here many times and for the price ($7-10) you get a lot of food.  I noticed that they have new management now and the service is still good.  My favorite is the Kal-bi!  But anything with Kim Chee in it has got to be good!  The Ban Chan (little dishes) are very good and always a treat.
author: Bill B.

description:
If a place can't make a good Kimchi then it's hard to give them a good review. I would give them average or above if I could do something with the food. I read the reviews here and was craving Korean food and made reservations and when the food came we looked at each other hoping it would taste better than it looked. 

The presentation was not attractive and the food was not on par. I wavered between 2 and 3 stars but the breaking point was the service. 

They are very nice but if I have to ask 5 times to get a 7up for my daughter then it's hard to praise them. The place only had two other tables to serve. 

I called in advance to get a good table and they put us at a table by the emergency exit. Do not sit here, the doors make noise and there is a draft. Move tables. 

There must be a better Korean place in the city. I need to try them all or wait until I go to LA. Bummer, I was hoping Dong Baek would be a shining star in the Tenderloin but no, it will be hard for me to visit again.
author: James T.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised here.  I thought that since the place was in the 'loin and no other korean places really near by, that the food would be decent at best but it was really tasty.  nice banchans served up, and the kimchi jigae was really on par with how i like it.  also a secret for english speakers on the menu is the duk bok ki, or spicy rice cake.  it is only written in korean on the menu so make sure to ask for it.
also, i liked the fact that the hostess was also the server, the busser, the phone answerer, and maybe even the cook :)  she was really nice and very cute in an older korean lady sort of way.
author: Andrew r.

description:
If you would have caught up to me a couple of years back my good Yelpers, I would have said, "Dong Baek?  Sheesh.  I'll Dong Baek you!  FOUR STARS my brethren."  However, a few years, alterations and price increases on their Lunch Specials later and I'm more like, "Don Baek?  Kim chi and stuff, bul go ki, kim chi gee gei... bla bla bla, I don't know, three stars?"

That being said, Dong Baek is still tasty, albeit a tad pricier than I'd like.  You do get a wealth of stuff for your buck though.  Although nobody cares, let me tell you a bit about Dong Baek's glory days.  Here is a little story.

Years ago when Suri Cruise was no more than a twinkle in her mama's eye, I would frequent Dong Baek for a lunch special to go.  Some kind of go khi, or BBQ'd meat, served along with whatever kinds of treats they wanted to add to it.  A little of this, a little of that.  Perhaps some cat treat or fried something.  Mystery substances that tasted like fish, swimming around my styrofoam trough in an equally mysterious liquid.  Gone are the days of the meat physically hitting the grill just prior to pick up.  Now I think they wrap it in foil and just reheat the stuff.  Don't thing that I am complaining though.  I am eating it while I am writing this review.
author: Jeff B.

description: They know me here!  Good food especially for lunch Monday thru friday
author: Shelley M.

description: We went for lunch on a Tuesday and there were not many people there. Our waiter was polite and attentive. The cham pong is amazing if you like seafood. Vegetarians: get the kimchi bibimbap.
author: Mark F.

description:
This place is so disappointing.  Food is disappointing.
Unfortunately, this one seems to be the only Korean restaurant in downtown nearby Union SQ.  

I ordered fish from the lunch menu that comes with rice and soup.  Soup is not served, so I asked for it later.  The waitress said that she thought I do not need it since my friend ordered a hot pot.  She did not even ask.  She "thought" that I didn't need, so she didn't serve it, although I paid for it.  

I agree with Sabrina that their service sucks. 
The waitress included 15% tip when I asked for a check (We were only 4 and there was no such a thing on the menu  or anywhere that 15% gratitude will be included).  
I would've missed it if I didn't look at the check. 
When asked, she said that because we want to avoid extra transaction fee for the credit card.  Then, she bruntly said, "you should give me cash tip if you don't want to charge it to your credit card."   What the...

I will never go this place again.
author: Leo P.

description:
If you miss Korean food, you must go here. It makes me feel like being in korea. 
I went with two french friends. They tried to eat Korean food and they liked as much as i like. There is many Korean food. If you don't like spicy food, you can order not spicy food. 
I recommend eating in here. you might be happy throughout eating Korean food.
author: Chaewook L.

description: Love it here! The got great Korean small appetizers dishes that's all tasty and free. Nice atmosphere and great place to show your friends a good Korean spot in SF. Definitely get the seafood pancake here.
author: kelly t.

description:
Jennifer Lopez and I have never really seen eye-to-eye, but in the case of Dong Baek, I will borrow a chapter out of her career and adamantly declare "Enough." After three times at this place, each visit increasingly more disappointing than the other, I'm crestfallen to conclude that if you want decent Korean food in this part of the world you're gonna have to pay a price-- $2.00 for a MUNI ride to the Richmond district.

There really isn't much of a problem with Dong Baek, if you don't put freshness at high priority and you've got a sweet tooth. All the spicy items are far too bland to actually bring you to tears, but the tears come anyway because of the confusion disappointment that you experience in the sugary, syrupy sauces. The only dish that worked in favor of this flaw was the tofu kimchi, a pile of sauteed kimchi and pork served with unseasoned tofu on the side. The contrast of the sweetened spicy-sour cabbage (and it's seasoned ok, since kimchi is so salty to begin with) with the innocent plain tofu is actually incredibly complex and enjoyable; it would have been better had the tofu been cold and the kimchi seasoned more liberally with salt and sesame oil. The black bean noodles are acceptable, still on the sweet side. What could potentially be a wonderful dish in the pan-fried jjam-ppong (saucy instead of soupy) is completely sullied by sugar and not enough heat. The bu dae chi gae is a travesty, littered with too many embarrasing applications of meat to be enjoyable. You may be thinking, what is she expecting from a dish whose main ingredients are Spam and hot dogs? But there's a right way to do it and a wrong, fake-Gucci-bag way to do it. C'mon, Dong Baek, there's no sense in trying to take shortcuts in this dish.

If Ms. Lopez and I were ever to meet and she wanted to go get some K-dinner, I would definitely not take her here. As much as I appreciate the effort, letting Dong Baek get me again would be akin to going back to the abusive arms of Billy Campbell. And to think one is supposed to pay 50 cents for the after-dinner coffee at a Korean restaurant.... don't even get me started.
author: Nuri K.

description: Delicious and I will definitely be back. Lots of more ethnic dishes than an Americanized Korean place. I only had take-out, but the service and the people were very accommodating and recommending a variety of dishes. I liked it!
author: Christopher C.

description: Been here twice for dinner and my experience has been very good. Its never busy here not sure why. Very few customers even for weekend dinner time. I usually get the regualr seafood pancake, hot fish sea bass soup and bbq chicken. very delicious. My friends ordered the cold noodle with some broth in it. I didnt really care for that.  I would come here again if I am around the neighborhood.
author: Tony W.

description:
Hello Dong Baek! Where have you been all my life? Dong Baek is a hidden gem in the TL that I love, love, love! I usually get take out from here and have only actually eaten at the place itself once. I usually get their lunch specials which on average cost around $10. I alternate between their Kal Bi (bbq ribs) or Beef Chap Chae and both are mouth watering nom nom nom goodness. For their lunch specials it's a small portion of rice with the item you ordered, kim chi, and a side of veggies. I once ordered beef chap chae after lunch hours and got two huge take out boxes... one was rice and the other was the beef chap chae. It's so huge that you could divide amongst two people or split it for lunch and dinner. That cost $13 which is cheap considering that 1) it's only $3 more than the lunch price and 2) it's a huge portion of food. The woman (who I am assuming is the owner) always serves my coworker and I tea when we wait for our take out. I had a cold once and like a good Asian mom she made me drink the tea she had made. The staff is very friendly and even friendlier when they recognize you.
P.S. Next time I go there for lunch I will be trying their Bal Go Gi!
author: selina n.

description:
I was really sick when I finally got up the courage to slip in the doors of Dong Baek, hanging on my boyfriend's arm with wide eyes.  I live literally right next door and yet had never eaten there before - partially because I've never had Korean food in my life and partially because it always looked a little too empty and maybe TOO authentic.  I didn't want to totally embarrass myself!

But it was late and I had just come from the ER and we needed fresh food, stat..  and one of my expectations did come true.  we totally embarrassed ourselves.  we ordered the dinner for 2 and were baffled when all these little condiment bowls came out.  when we asked for a little guidance regarding korean cuisine, the waiter just shrugged and said "appetizer."  not very helpful.  At one point, the waiter was laughing really hard as my boyfriend tried to eat some slippery noodles and he brought out a fork.

over all... i give the experience three stars.  the food was only ok - but i'm clearly no expert.  the service was minimal and unhelpful - though mostly due to language barriers.  it was comfortable and quiet, but... I would not dine here again.  I'm really very disappointed!  I have loved all foods from Asia until now.
author: Rei E.

description: Not much has changed at Dong Baek.  While it's not the best Korean food in the world, it is one of the few places open in the wee hours of the night and feeds 7 for $100 (pretax and tip).  Hard to beat.
author: Laurence H.

description:
Tasty korean restaurant located in the bowels of San Francisco -- er, I mean, the Tenderloin.  

It's pretty quiet, the food is as good as any Korean restaurant in the city, and you won't come out smelling bad. All in all, a solid place.
author: Tim G.

description:
So I went here with my other two coworkers for our "monthly" lunch out of the office together. (Monthly in quotes because we sort of not do it monthly, but whatever.)  So we went after wanting Korean food for a while.  So we came here.   Not that crowded for a lunch time and somehow we got stuck in a corner with a weird smell to it. But to the food.

So we got about 7 of the little plates of banchan to eat  good kimchee, okay broccoli (first time I had broccoli as a banchan) and cucumber and chapjae.  Good way to start.  So we decided to split a bulbogi, kimchi jji gae and a Galbi.   The bulbogi was okay, lacking flavor and a bit rubbery, I had better bulbogi elsewhere.  The galbi on the other hand was excellent.  Nice and tender and very well executed.  So was the kimchi jjigae which was nice and spicy with tofu and beef in the mixed.  We also order a bottle of soju and never again will I do that for lunch again, my dear friend decided to tell me to be a man and finish it off....and I had 6 small glasses of those....ack....

Service was attentive and prompt since there wasn't a lot of us around to begin with.   

Will definitely head back again.
author: Chris C.

description: I came here for lunch a while back... it was pretty bad. Another failed attempt at Korean food in the city. :(
author: Cheri S.

description: Not very good. Craving Korean, and this just didn't add up. The little appetizer/side dishes are my favorite, and they were lacking in flavor, variety, and freshness. One of them was over-steamed broccoli. Lame. The tofu soup was lacking. MUCH better at My Tofu House. The Ja-Jang noodles were ok,  but nothing to write home about. Hardly satisfied the Korean craving. Maybe we ordered wrong? Its a huge menu...but these were pretty standard dishes.
author: Lauren Q.

description:
Like every other korean restaurant, they have a lunch special during the week. Ive been here a handful of times. the food is mediocre but the price is great. i think its like $7 for your entree and  comes with some kind of MSG soup that i dont care for and those little plates they give you with your meal. my favs: cucumber and kim chee.  ive ordered the bim bum bob and the bul go gi special before and they give you A LOT for it.  the taste isnt the best but you cant complain too much if its only like 7 buckaroos. 
the lady that seems to work there every single time (must be the owner) is super nice and is nto cheap bout giving us extra kimchee. well, we've only asked once but she gave it to us without reservation. my two complaints: you gotta go through the smelly streets in the TL and the water smell of funk. either bring your own or order a can of soda or something.
author: Bren L.

description: I eat here often for their dol sot bibim bop..... SOOO good.  They serve generous proportions, legit Korean food and fast, friendly service.
author: Ted T.

description: We had a feast here, three friends and I, and though I'm no authority on Korean food, I'd say that it was quite excellent. Dumplings were great, the chap chae very flavorful, the bibimbap well crisped, and the kalbi actually incredible. Panchan selection was good, though not as varied as some other places I've been. The only missed beat was a beef soup which, I must be honest, the only sip of which I took tasted like dusty water to me. But hey, probably an acquired taste. In any case, 3.5 stars which someday I might round up to 4. Give it a try!
author: Peter B.

description: If you're into Ja Jung Myun, this place has it.  It's not the best here, but this isn't LA.  It's tough to find decent Korean food in the city, but this place has it.  Super expensive - $20 for Kalbi - you're kidding right?  But their noodles aren't super pricey.  I would honestly hit this up for it's lunch menu.  Service isn't bad, a bit on the slow side but worth the wait.
author: Nick H.

description:
'deng jang ji gae' and 'su rul tang' are delicious.

one time my girlfriend asked for 'porridge', they make it for her, even it's not in the menu. ( she was sick though and she's korean..of course :-))
good for large group.
parking is quite a problem.
author: Suki S.

description:
Well, expected too much. I heard it's one of the best Korean restaurant in town but I have to say I've had better. 
I tried 'soon do bu jji gae' & 'bibim bap' and especially the soup was too watery and not spicy enough.
author: Sunmi S.

description: 10 side dishes provided for three of us. that was nice. but  two of the three entrees ordered were just ok.
author: Paiyu G.

description: New management = Much Better Food. I love korean food therefore i am super picky. Their menu is full of varieties. Their fish egg is pretty good, which is very important to me. Frequent customer and will be for a long time.
author: Frankie L.

description: Homemade Korean food-normal meaty menu with plenty of veggie options. Their garlic tofu is off the chain especially when paired with any one of their soups with homemade noodles.
author: TeamHellaSwag ..

description:
I have been to Dong Baek several times since I came to San Francisco. Actually the first time that I tried Korean food was there. After that I visited other korean restaurants but Dong Baek is still my favorite. 
Usually the restaurant is not crowd and you don't need to wait for a table. The restaurant also accepts reservations but I have never tried to make one.
The ambience is quiet and nice and they have big tables to receive big groups. The service is excellent the waiters are polite and fast.
The menu is big and they also have some pictures of the dishes and good explanation about how the dishes are. I think this is good because I'm not Korean and sometimes its hard to know which food I should order.
I'm Brazilian and I really love meat and barbecue, so I recommend ordering galbi or samgyeopsal. You can also try the bi-bim-bap or noodles. To drink I usually order soju, the famous korean alcohol drink, but if you have never tried this drink and are not used to drinking strong things you should be careful.
All the food there is always tasty, delicious and fresh. The portions are big and you can share with a friend.
Dong Baek is not expensive, I usually spent $15,00 to $20,00 if I drink just water, when I drink some alcoholic drink I spent a little more.
This restaurant never disappoints me and I recommend it to everyone.
author: Vinny B.

description: And I thought all the Korean restaurants were on Geary. This place is in the TL near Union Square and when you walk in the interior is a little off, a little low budget but man do they bring the food out fast, hot and actually really good. Me and a couple coworkers stopped by here last night for dinner and ordered large Hite beers, haemul paejon (seafood pancake), tang su yuk (Korean style sweet n sour pork), dok boki (thick spicy rice noodle with squid, bul kogi, and chap chae. All the dishes were tasty. I would recommend going here since...well...it's pretty much the only Korean place in that entire area.
author: David C.

description:
I'm always in search of additional options for soon dubu closer to my hood than My Tofu House. I'm lazy like that. I also enjoy trying new places. So today I gave Dong Baek a shot for lunch. I ordered the number 14 lunch special for $7.25 - Soon Tofu Chi Gae - soft bean cake casserole with hot bean paste, vegetable and beef. About 6 different panchan (and a bowl of rice of course) came with it. Nothing super interesting or different with the panchan except for a dish of tempura style green beans topped with a dark sweet sauce. 

The dish is really a soup, not a casserole per se, and contained two mysterious oysters not indicated on the menu. No complaints from me, I liked them, but someone else may not appreciate their unannounced appearance. There was also precious little visible beef. Unlike My Tofu House, you aren't given the option of regulating the spice level here. I normally order mild at My Tofu House and add kimchee or hot sauce if I think it needs more kick. Here, it just comes out one way - red, hot and bubbling up at you with a dare. You might say I was dragged out of the shallow end of the Korean hot bean paste pool and drop kicked into the deep zone. I survived quite well. Although I did ask for (uhhhh...ok, NEEDED) an additional serving of the only two cooling panchan - the bean sprout salad and the daikon salad. I also missed the raw egg that I've been offered at other places serving soon dubu. So even though the soup was fairly tasty, it lacked the silky texture and slight mellowing effect mixing in the egg provides. 

Dong Baek has an attractive and spacious traditional interior, with lots of warm carved wood and some private dining alcoves. The friendly single server did a good job of covering the tables all on her own. I can't say I was big fan of the sappy 80's soft rock radio playing in the background. Overall, I am glad I tried it, but no, no nearby substitute was found for My Tofu House. I guess I just need to light a fire under my lazy ass. Lol. Come to think of it, that is one thing Dong Baek did quite well. :-D
author: wendella a.

description:
A very good lil' Korean restaurant - think of it as "neighborhood Korean joint".

They've got good & many banchan (sides), a huge menu with some interesting dishes, like Samgyetang (ginseng chicken soup), not just standards like kalbi etc., and the food was rather tasty (esp. the pajeon = scallion pancakes) - and fast!

The portions are huge - one dish is enough for one and a half or two people. (For a couple, one appetizer and one main are enough, even if you're quite hungry.)

That said: the decor is pretty cheap, I'd prefer smaller portions of main dishes (and accordingly smaller prices), and while the food is good, it's not especially exciting.

If you want good Korean home cooking in SF proper, order less than one dish per person (easiest with a crowd), and don't mind having a plastic menu and being in the Tenderloin, it's a great option!
author: Nils B.

description: I just worked with a bunch of Korean guys who were on their first trip to the U.S.  When they tired of trying all of the other cuisines SF has to offer, this is where they would go.  They assured me that it was good and authentic -- tho they complained about having to pay for the side dishes, which isn't common in Seoul.
author: Karen T.

description: The food is too greasy and kind of expensive. The spicy cuttlefish was ok but the Ox tails were too fatty and the potatoes weren't cooked enough. The best part of the meal was the seaweed salad. They do put out all the little bowls different Kim Chi if you are into that kind of thing. To be fair I wanted to order one of their pot stews but my friend wanted to share entree's so I'll give them another try some time and order what I generally like.
author: Manny F.

description: The location may not be easy to find. But the food is very very good. Its BBQ pork is very tasteful and everybody should try it.
author: mc a.

description:
bomb.
i have lived really close to this place and it took almost a year for me to actually go there. its a great place for dates or groups as the menu is very family style. its a lot larger inside that what it looks like from outside. they have a lot of different varieties of sake right at the door so you can think about what you want with your meal. our server (somebody's crazy aunt) came up to us and said "ohhhh you like sake....i like sake" i sure she has a few everyday. they were really friendly and the food was great. we ordered the bbq short ribs and they came out in on  smoking plate (kind fajita style) it also came with rice and bunch of lil appetitizers. we also got the fried fish was just as good as the ribs. i think we may have went a little over board in ordering but we very impressed with everything! it can get pretty expensive if there are just two people but i think with a little larger of a group it def becomes a great value as you can share everything.
author: Ashley H.

description:
Overall, I'd say this place is ok.  It falls comfortably between fancy restaurant and hole in the wall, with an extensive menu and reasonable prices.  Good assortment of banchan, and I think they have duk bokki (will try ordering next time;  snapped a cell phone pic of a menu item posted on the wall that was written only in korean, with the intention of asking a friend to translate but haven't gotten around to it yet).

HOWEVER.  My most recent visit was pretty disappointing.  If I were to base my review solely on that visit, Dong Baek would only be getting two stars....  I had been obsessing about spicy, piping hot soon doobu for days, but was too lazy to trek out to My Tofu House and endure any sort of wait.  I thought that perhaps Dong Baek, conveniently located only blocks away in my 'hood, could adequately quell the craving.  I was sorely and sadly mistaken.

My soon doobu came out warm/hot enough for a regular soup, but it did not come out boiling in its own bowl like it should be.  It also wasn't spicy at all, despite my having emphasized that I wanted it spicy.  Beyond that, there wasn't much depth of flavor, and the soggy zucchini (a vegetable which has minimal flavor itself) didn't improve things.
