I tried to make do by adding some kimchi and other banchan to bites, which helped,  but eventually I'd had enough Mickey Mousing around -- I was in the mood for SPICY food, damnit -- so I asked if I could get some hot sauce or something.  The woman (she appeared to be the proprietress) had somewhat limited english skills, but when the message got through that I was looking to augment the spice level ("Ohhh, spicy ok?" she asked incredulously), she ran back into the kitchen and returned with a container of red paste.  Even after mixing a couple heaping spoonfuls into my soup, it still barely had any spice, though at least it was a little more flavorful.

Not sure what the deal was.  I have a suspicion that maybe my food was dumbed down because I'm not Korean and was dining with a white boy.  Towards the end of our meal, a table of Koreans across from us were served a soup that was furiously bubbling away in its little cauldron, and I spied something that resembled a squeeze bottle of spiciness on their table as well.

I'm sure I'll return to see if they have duk bokki as rumored, but I don't know if I'll get soon doobu here again (though I remember it being decent in the past).  It was just THAT disappointing and unsatisfying.  Life's too short to risk wasting a meal on another bland soon doobu, y'know?
author: daphne w.

description: I threw a birthday party here and it was quite successful. The food came fast and was very yummy. I love their bul-go-gi. The waitor was so cool. He keeps bringing in the soju and beer. He had so much fun, it was like it was also his party. At the end of the night, I got sprayed with champagne. It was fun, but my clothes smelled afterwards!
author: Helen L.

description: Food was not impressive. I have eaten at good Korean restaurants before, and they tasted 'ok but weird' -- this one was 'just not that good'. Service was even worse. The waitress came to our table only twice although we were one of only 2 tables! We had to get up and find her to get and pay the bill. It's also way overpriced for the quality, 10-20 bucks a dish. AVOID THIS TASTELESS MONEY PIT!
author: cc v.

description: Shatangi, Evelyn and I went here to celebrate our 100th review.  It was actually a great little find in the middle of the loin.  Cute decor inside and good signage outside.  Food was good.  I really enjoyed the dol sot bi bim bab but the seafood pancake was a little soggy but tasty.  By the end of the meal, every square inch of our table was filled with little dishes, glasses and evidence of our very big appetitites.  One of my fave Korean places so far.
author: Dana C.

description: $11 for jjambong noodle soup.... that should explain why I gave this place 2 stars. I happened to be in the city and was craving for the soup. I was too tired to drive to East Bay although it cost twice as much and tasted just okay. The broth didn't have much flavor and had bunch of hot pepper and oil. If I don't get lucky with parking, I doubt that I would come again.
author: Cuddles C.

description: Ok, I used to come here a lot becuz the stupid ass hole of a bf I was dating loved this place. However this was probably the highlight of the relationship when I look back at it. What the relationship has to with this restaurant? nothing, just htat I remember this place being yum. Their Kai bi, Kim Chi chege, and the service is sweet ^_^. It's in a fabulous area too Tenderloin! Can't get more ghetto than that! (Ok I was being sarcastic) Anyway, parking is a bitch, but 38 bus will take you there. You can't miss it, it's accross from hwere the old Naan and Curry Used to be (if memory serves me correct) go try it. ^_^
author: Bianca L.

description:
Untalented Cook in the kitchen!!

Recent ownership changed think year or two ago.  Bottom line: Save your money.  For SF area korean restaurant, I'd give two star but as a korean restaurant.  prompt attention was good.  one of my pet peeve is that appetizer come at the same time as entree...seafood pancake was 3 start but pretty plain...shrimps has shells on them (tail portion)...WTF?? take that s**t off before you cook!!!  ordered fried kimchi and tofu which is known to be order with Soju (korean grain alcohol) or beer...it tasted flat...no complexity what-so-ever...very salty with crap load of MSG...some that gets cooked by untalented mothers what cooks fishes out of the box.  i know my dogs won't eat it.  most disappointing...ordered nang myun (cold broth noodle - it was 88F in SF this day...very hot for SF) with sa-ri (this means extra portion of noodle)  when the noodle came...no hot mustard, no vinegar...had to ask for them...noodle broth tasted very sour...it suppose to be beef broth...and diner can add vinegar and hot mustard to their taste...sa-ri (extra noodle with no addition broth...how do they expect eat that extra noodle)  so far, most restaurant when sa-ri is orderd, there comes extra portion of noodle in a bowl with 'broth' in it...bad business practice...don't they not wanna provide a good dining experience so they will have a repeat customer???  this restaurant USED to be so GOOD

one of way I can tell crappy restaurant is they make it salty...salt does bring out the flavor but not when masquerade it all over...that's sign of sh**ty arse cook.  food price is avg for SF not cheap.  take your $$$ to go oakland or berkeley for korean food.  go only if you don't care what the food taste like but want more than USDA recommended sodium intake...you will leave happy and bloated

we left with a bad taste (MSG) in the mouth...

sundays they open for dinner only
author: B K.

description:
this place was pretty good. it reminded me of those old school korean restaurants back in the day with low lighting and wood paneling. the food was nothing special, but i liked that the restaurant felt VERY korean. kudos for the abundance of banchan and the plentiful offerings of "service." although i didn't order it, i was STOKED to see they had kimchi bokkumbab on the menu. yuuuum. 

dana c and shatangi gave it 4 stars (my lovely dinner companions for the night), but i gave it 3 because i'm korean and i'm a harder judge of all things korean. actually, it's because i'm just a big bitch and i can't be pleased by any korean food other than my mother's.
author: eve l.

description: My boyfriend and I usually eat here if we want something healthy or a lot of vegetables! We love how they always serve the multiple little bowls of various korean veggies, fishcakes, and kimchi when we first sit. And they hot tea is pretty good, not like regular tea from chinese resturaunts. Their prices are just a tad extreme but I guess it's worth it since it's so authentic. But we usually try to catch the lunch special from 11am to 3pm..way cheaper but not as much variety. We give them 4 stars only because everything is well prepared and tastey but if the waiters and waitresses don't really make it a memorable experience. you know when you show up in a place a bunch of times and they start to recognize your face so you two kind of know eachother already?
author: kirehleen f.

description: I have tried most Korean places in SF and this place is the worst. My friends and I (all of us Korean) went for an early dinner to get samgyupsal and soju. We ordered 2 orders of samgyupsal and jjam pong. The jampong was okay, but the waitress brought out two big dishes piled with luke-warm samgyupsal.. We were very disappointed since we had been expecting to grill it from our table. Had we known, we would have ordered something else. We were miserable stuck with two huge piles of cold samgyupsal and ended up leaving most of it.. I will never go back again
author: Alexi P.

description: I don't care if I come out smelling like eau de BBQ.  This is my place for MEAT!  Their kalbi is the perfect balance of juicy beef and crisped fat, all temptingly hinged on a tasty short rib.  But wait!  There's more.  Their array of pickled nibblies will take you to kimchee heaven.
author: M A N I K.

description: Once you get over the shock at finding a large, quiet, clean, atmospheric, full service restaurant in the middle of the Tenderloin the reality sets in and it becomes yet another Korean restaurant.  The clay pot beef/tofu soup we had was medium spicy, hearty, and overall pretty good.  Reasonable prices.  A little low on the joy + celebration + party feel, more just a place to come and eat.  All the usual condiments to fill up on and it's open from 11-11 everyday.
author: Gil S.

description: I am not Korean, I am a vegetarian, and I haven't been able to like fermented foods, so I am probably not qualified to review a Korean restaurant. I like to order the dol sot bi bim bap with no beef, which unlike plain bi bim bap, comes in the stone bowl with a raw egg on top. This may be the only vegetarian option, but that's ok because I really like it. They give you the usual 10 bowls of pickled items before your meal. My dining companion likes this place because they serve cold soup noodles, which has apple, radish, and hard boiled egg. Get a big bottle of Korean beer to share.
author: Amy E.

description:
When I lived in the neighborhood, I never went there.  Because they had photos of food that are so faded, they just looked so unappetizing.   However, I went there with a group of friends because it was there and we had no good reason not to go there.  

Not a bad Korean place.  Big enough to have Korean style drinking night out.  You know what I mean!  Price is a bit higher than I would like to pay but if you want to try average Korean, it is a place in TL.
author: Su Kyeong K.

description: It's okay, if you're stuck in the area, and need to satisfy a korean-food craving.  Otherwise, go somewhere else.
author: Matt P.

description: Sundubu jjigae was good.  Too bad I am addicted to it....guess that's not too bad considering I live in this neighborhood.
author: Gillian F.

description: no frills, just really excellent food.  and by "excellent" i really mean "average" but  if you like a quiet hole-in-the-wall with decent food and decent prices, then it certainly rates "excellent."
author: Samantha W.

description: Under new ownership.  Best Jja Jang Myun and Jjam Bbong.  Other stuff is awesome too.  Great menu and great prices.  I highly recommend.
author: Phil M.

description: You wouldn't expect to find a restaurant  in this neck of the woods or on the ground floor of  an apartment complex  in this Civic Center neighborhood, but Dong Baek will surprise you.  Forget Brother's on Geary, this place is the real deal.  You won't find a line forming with people who are not Korean, but you will find great tasting Korean food.  My favorites are the steam dishes, kori jim (oxtail) and kalbi jim (beef  short  ribs).   Ask for a table in a booth or sit on the floor Korean style.  Bring some friends, get a bottle of soju or  bok bun ja (raspberry  wine), munch on the dozen or so kimchee sampler and chow on  down.  If you're down for the Korean experience, keep the soju flowing and catch a cab on the way out.
author: Steve C.

description: I've been here 3x at least, and fortunately didn't have the experience some others had.  Twice we ordered a feast.  All was good.  Once I ordered take out for a soup I don't even like, but it was nutritious for my situation at the time.  And I loved it.  Their version of the soup converted me to liking the soup itself.  And they'd respected my wish for no shellfish.  I've always had good service here.  It's not on par with Korean restaurants in the east bay, south bay, NY or LA, but it's quite okay.  That rhyme wasn't intentional tho.
author: S M.
